Contents.Text: Cardiac disease associated with Lyme disease
Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi from an
Ixodes spp. tick bite. Patients who display signs of illness or fever within 30
days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for tick-borne illness.
In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human anaplasmosis, babesiosis, and
Powassan virus disease. Patients who have been bitten by an Ixodes spp. tick
(deer tick) but who do not display signs or symptoms of infection should not
Prophylactic antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain patients who
have been bitten while in endemic areas.
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult disease to
diagnose and treat. Infectious Diseases consultation is strongly encouraged.
Mandell Chapter: Lyme Disease (Lyme Borreliosis) Due to Borrelia burgdorferi

Contents.Text: Patients with impaired splenic function are at risk for severe and
and overwhelming infection with encapsulated bacteria. Streptococcus
pneumoniae is the most common cause of fulminant sepsis in patients with
impaired splenic function, followed by Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria
If fever develops in an asplenic patient, immediate administration of an
antimicrobial agent is indicated, because fever can be the initial
manifestation of a fulminant infection and prompt administration of an
antimicrobial agent may prevent the development of clinical sepsis.

Contents.Text: Mediastinitis occurs after cardiothoracic procedures or less commonly after
esophageal perforation.  Rarely, infectious diseases of the head, neck or thorax
spread into the mediastinum.  Surgical drainage and antimicrobial therapy are
both essential.  Specific management depends on the source of infection.  Obtain
aerobic and anaerobic cultures in all cases.
Inhalational anthrax (due to Bacillus anthracis) typically presents as
mediastinitis with cough productive of hemorrhagic secretions.  This disease
should be considered in a patient without typical risk factors for mediastinitis
or in the setting of suspected or confirmed bioterrorism.  If anthrax is
suspected, page the Infectious Diseases service.
Mixed aerobic/anaerobic infection is often present.
Treatment AFTER ESOPHAGEAL PERFORATION OR RUPTURE

4) Administration will begin within 5 days of symptom onset.

which elevated concentrations are associated with serious and/or
5) Co-administration with potent CYP3A inducers where significantly reduced
nirmatrelvir or ritonavir plasma concentrations may be associated with the
potential for loss of virologic response and possible resistance.
1) The concomitant use of PAXLOVID and certain other drugs may result in

information prior to and during treatment for potential drug interactions.

jaundice have occurred in patients receiving ritonavir.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NOT BENEFITED PHARYNGITIS

Contents.Text: Acute pharyngitis is common, accounting for 2 percent of all
ambulatory visits in the United States.  The major treatable pathogen, group
A streptococcus (GAS), is the cause of pharyngitis in only approximately 10
percent of adults who seek medical care.  The vast majority of patients
receive presumptive antibiotic therapy for pharyngitis which in most cases is
unnecessary and results in adverse effects including death, increases costs,
and adds to pressure on antimicrobial resistance.  Typical causes of
pharyngitis include viruses in about ¼, beta-hemolytic streptococci other
than group A in 18%, Mycoplasma pneumoniae in 10%, Chlamydophila pneumoniae
in 8%, Group A streptococci in 5%, and no microbe identified in 1/3.
Rheumatic fever is rare in the United States, especially in adults, so
that some authorities recommend no treatment even if GAS is a potential cause
of pharyngitis.Others feel it is important to detect GAS  since antibiotic
therapy can slightly shorten the acute illness, prevent acute rheumatic fever
and possibly prevent suppurative sequelae.  Other potential causes of
pharyngitis that should be considered and diagnosed if likely include
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) mononucleosis, primary HIV infection, influenza,
gonococcal pharyngitis, diphtheria, and suppurative pharyngeal infections.
The Centor criteria are used to predict whether GAS pharyngitis is present.
If three or four of these criteria are met, the positive predictive value is
40 to 60 percent.  If fewer than three criteria are present, the likelihood
GAS is causing pharyngitis is less than 20 percent.  If 3 or > Centor criteria
are met, obtain a throat culture for group A streptococcus.  Treat
empirically for GAS if the patient has severe symptoms or treat later for GAS
if the throat culture is positive.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NOT BENEFITTED BACTERIURIA

Contents.Text: Treatment of Candida Urinary Tract Infections
Asymptomatic bacteriuria (>= 100,000 bacteria per ml of urine) is common in
middle aged and older people, especially those who have chronic medical
conditions. Pyuria is common in persons with bacteriuria and individuals with
indwelling catheters in place. By itself, the presence of pyuria is not
sufficient to diagnose bacteriuria, and the presence or absence of pyuria does
not differentiate symptomatic from asymptomatic urinary infection. Candiduria is
less common than bacteriuria, but the implications of candiduria are similar to
Many studies, including randomized clinical trials have shown that
treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria and candiduria, with or without pyuria is
of no benefit, except in certain well-defined circumstances. Antimicrobial
therapy is always accompanied by risk of harms, including drug reactions,
Clostridium difficile colitis, anaphylaxis and death. Except in circumstances
specified below, it is best to not order urinalysis or urine culture in
asymptomatic persons. If bacteriuria, candiduria or pyuria is discovered in an
asymptomatic person for some reason, antimicrobial therapy should not be given
Pregnant women or patients undergoing urological procedures with bacteriuria

Conditions Not Benefited by Antimicrobial Therapy
Several common conditions associated with inflammation or
microorganisms do not benefit from antibiotic therapy in most or all
cases. Yet, antimicrobials are frequently prescribed for those conditions
leading to unnecessary toxicity and costs, rare deaths, and the relentless
increase in antimicrobial resistance. Please review these conditions and
do not give antimicrobials for these conditions unless there are
extraordinary circumstances that make your situation different. If you
have any questions, please contact the infectious disease physician

Several common conditions associated with inflammation or
microorganisms do not benefit from antibiotic therapy in most or all cases.
Yet, antimicrobials are frequently prescribed for these conditions leading to

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NR BACTERURIA ETC

Contents.Item: ORZ ADD MENU UROLOGY CONSULT MENU

Contents.Text: Bacteruria (>= 100,000 bacteria per ml of urine) is found in 1 or 2
percent of healthy young children. Bacteruria becomes more common in females
after menarche, occurring in ~5 percent of young women. The incidence
increases substantially after middle age such that from 10 to 16 percent of
healthy people over age 55 years living in the community have bacteruria.
The incidence is 15 to 40% of people over age 55 living in long-term care
institutions. The incidence in people with chronic diseases is increased
compared with healthy people. Candiduria is less common, but the
implications of candiduria are similar to those of bacteruria.
Table 2. Prevalence of asymptomatic bacteruria in selected populations.
Elderly persons in a long-term care facility
Pyuria is common in persons with bacteruria. Pyuria is present with
asymptomatic bacteruria in ~32% of young women, 30%-70% of pregnant women,
70% of diabetic women, 90% of elderly institutionalized patients, 90% of
hemodialysis patients, 30%-70% of bacteruric patients with short-term
catheters in place, and 50%-100% of individuals with long-term indwelling
catheters in place. Thus, by itself, the presence of pyuria is not
sufficient to diagnose bacteruria, and the presence or absence of pyuria does
not differentiate symptomatic from asymptomatic urinary infection.
Many studies, including randomized clinical trials have shown that
treatment of asymptomatic bacteruria, with or without pyuria is of no
benefit, except in three well-defined circumstances. Antimicrobial therapy
is always accompanied by risk of harms, including drug reactions, Clostridium
difficile colitis, anaphylaxis and death. Except in circumstances specified
below, it is best to not order urinalysis or urine culture in asymptomatic
persons. If bacteruria or pyuria is discovered in an asymptomatic person for
some reason, antimicrobial therapy should not be given except as specified
Pregnant women have an increased incidence of bacteruria, from 2 to
10%. The risk of pyelonephritis in pregnant women with bacteruria is
increased 25-fold. Antimicrobial therapy to eradicate bacteruria in pregnant
women reduces the risk of pyelonephritis. Pregnant women should be tested
for bacteruria and treated if it is detected.
Persons with bacteruria (defined for this situation as 10,000 or more
bacteria/ml) who undergo traumatic genitourinary procedures associated with
mucosal bleeding are at increased risk for post-procedure bacteruria and
sepsis. Persons about to have genitourinary procedures associated with
mucosal bleeding should be tested for bacteruria. If bacteruria is detected,
antimicrobial therapy should be initiated shortly before the procedure.
Antimicrobial therapy should not be continued beyond the procedure, unless an

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NR BLOOD CULTURE
DisplayText: Blood Culture Positive for Coagulase Negative Staphylococci

Contents.Text: BLOOD CULTURE POSITIVE FOR COAGULASE NEGATIVE STAPHYLOCOCCI
Coagulase negative staphylococci are the most common contaminants
isolated from blood cultures. One half of all positive blood cultures are
positive for coagulase negative staphylococci, and these positive cultures
positive because of contamination 90% of the time. When coagulase
negative staphylococci isolated from blood cultures represent true
bacteremia, the blood has nearly always been obtained from a patient with
plastic or metal in the body. The most common source of coagulase negative
staphylococcal bacteremia is an infected intravascular catheter.
When coagulase negative staphylococci are isolated from blood, the
physician should carefully assess the patient to decide whether the isolation
represents disease or colonization. Colonization is more likely if a single
bottle is positive or both bottles from a single blood draw are positive. If
multiple bottles are positive from separate blood draws, it is more likely
that the isolates reflect disease or colonization of an intravascular device.
Isolates from contaminated bottles often take several days to become
positive. If the patient has risk factors for true coagulase negative
staphylococcal bacteremia and/or the patient is severely ill, antimicrobials
should be given. If there is a vascular catheter, the catheter should be
removed and a new one inserted into a different site if at all possible. If
there is a plastic or metal prosthesis in the body, the physician should
evaluate the site for possible infection. If the isolates are likely to
represent contamination and the patient does not seem ill with coagulase
negative staphylococci, antimicrobial therapy would not be helpful and should
Link to treatment of infected catheters
Acute bronchitis is a clinical syndrome with a brief, self-limited
pneumonia on chest radiograph. It is accompanied by dry or productive
cough lasting up to 3 weeks, is most prevalent in winter, and is primarily
caused by viruses. More than 1 in 20 people have acute bronchitis per
year, with highest rates during the winter months. This discussion does
not pertain to acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis, a clinical
syndrome also frequently associated with viral infection, but in which
bacteria play a more important role.
decongestants, and beta 2-agonists have been used to treat patients
with acute bronchitis, but controlled trials have not clearly concluded
Empirical antibacterial therapy has repeatedly been shown to provide
no benefit for most patients. Acute bronchitis remains one of the five
most frequently cited rationales for excessive antibiotic use in
outpatients. Acute bronchitis and other acute respiratory syndromes
(otitis media, sinusitis, pharyngitis, upper respiratory infections)
account for approximately 75% of ambulatory prescriptions in the
United States. Current guidelines, endorsed by a number of national
societies, including the Infectious Diseases Society of America, do
not recommend the routine use of antibiotics for uncomplicated acute
If pertussis is suspected, early therapy with macrolides or
tetracyclines is indicated to prevent transmission, although the
clinical findings early in pertussis infection are indistinguishable
from viral causes of bronchitis, and the incidence of disease is very
low. Treat for pertussis only when a patient has likely been exposed
Asthma attacks often have symptoms resembling bronchitis. Asthma
attacks to not benefit from antimicrobial therapy.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NR COLONIZED VENT PTS
DisplayText: Colonized respiratory tract in patient with a ventilator

Contents.Text: COLONIZED RESPIRATORY TRACT IN A PATIENT ON A VENTILATOR
The respiratory tracts of persons who are intubated, have a
tracheostomy, or have other abnormalities of the larynx or trachea are
usually colonized with bacteria and often fungi. The bacteria can be of
relatively low virulence (e.g. coagulase negative staphylococci,
streptococci, candida) or of potentially greater virulence
enterococci are common respiratory tract colonizers and they almost
never cause pneumonia. There is no benefit from treatment of patients
with systemic antimicrobials simply because the respiratory tract is
colonized with a potential pathogen. Systemic antimicrobial therapy
will select for resistant organisms and may lead to other adverse effects.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NR COLONIZED WOUNDS

Contents.Text: Open wounds are usually colonized with bacteria and often fungi. This
is true of ulcers, post-operative wounds, traumatic wounds, and others. The
bacteria can be of relatively low virulence (e.g. coagulase negative
staphylococci, diphtheroids) or of potentially greater virulence
commonly present on wounds that are moist or covered. There is no need to
treat patients with systemic antimicrobials simply because a wound culture is
positive for a potential pathogen. Topical antimicrobials are not effective
in nearly all circumstances and select for resistant organisms or lead to
other adverse effects. Systemic antimicrobial therapy may be indicated if
Acute pharyngitis is common, accounting for 2 percent of all
ambulatory visits in the United States. The major treatable pathogen,
group A streptococcus (GAS), is the cause of pharyngitis in only
approximately 10 percent of adults who seek medical care. The vast
majority of patients receive presumptive antibiotic treatment for
pharyngitis which in most cases is unnecessary and results in adverse
effects including death, increases costs, and adds pressure on antimicrobial
resistance. Typical causes of pharyngitis include viruses in about
1/4, beta-hemolytic streptococci other than group A in 18%, Mycoplasma
pneumoniae in 10%, Chlamydophila pneumoniae in 8%, Group A streptococci
in 5%, and no microbe identified in 1/3.
Rheumatic fever is rare in the United States, especially in adults,
so that some authorities recommend no treatment even if GAS is a potential
cause of pharyngitis. Others feel it is important to detect GAS since
antibiotic therapy can slightly shorten the acute illness, prevent acute
rheumatic fever and possibly prevent suppurative sequelae. Other
potential causes of pharyngitis that should be considered and diagnosed
if likely include Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) mononucleosis, primary HIV
infection, influenza, gonococcal pharyngitis, diphtheria, and suppurative

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX NR STASIS DERM

Contents.Text: Stasis dermatitis is a common condition that is often confused with
bacterial cellulitis. Stasis dermatitis does not benefit from antimicrobial
therapy. It is important to distinguish between the two. The provider
should be mindful of the fact that bacterial cellulitis can occur on skin
with underlying stasis dermatitis. (See link below for bacterial cellulitis).
Common risk factors for venous stasis include advancing age, family
history of venous disease, increased body mass index, smoking, a history of
trauma, prior venous thrombosis and pregnancy. Chronic venous disease and
arterial vascular disease have some common risk factors (e.g. smoking,
obesity) and pathophysiological processes. The most common symptoms reported
by patients with chronic venous disease are limb discomfort (tired, heavy
legs), pain, and limb swelling. Swelling is often worse with prolonged
standing and improves with leg elevation and walking. The skin of the
anterior surfaces of the lower legs often has brown or blue-grey
People with venous stasis are prone to develop stasis dermatitis which
is one of the most common and earliest dermatologic signs of chronic venous
insufficiency. Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory process that presents as
an eczematous rash characterized by itching, erythema, scaling, weeping,
erosions, and crusting. Longstanding cases may develop lipodermatosclerosis,
a fibrosing panniculitis of the subcutaneous tissue. Lipodermatosclerosis
typically starts with a firm area of induration at the medial ankle. As the
process progresses, the entire lower leg can become involved with
extension up to the mid leg in more advanced cases. The skin overlying the
panniculitis is typically heavily pigmented and bound down to the
subcutaneous tissues. Brawny edema above the fibrotic area and on the foot
below is seen in advanced cases. Leukocytosis and fever are common in people
Chronic venous disease is the most common cause of leg ulcers. They
are usually found low on the medial ankle over a perforating vein, or along
the course of the great or small saphenous veins. They occur more proximally
if precipitated by trauma. Venous ulcers are not found on the forefoot or
above the level of the knee. Venous ulcers can be multiple or single, and
can be exquisitely tender, shallow, exudative and have a granulation base.
The ulcer borders are usually irregular but not undermined. They can extend
circumferentially around the leg if left untreated.
Arterial ulcers are typically painful, and punched out or stellate. The
surrounding skin is read and taut. Some arterial ulcers are pale - others have
a black or yellow eschar. They are often associated with trauma and commonly
occur on the foot over pressure points. There may be other signs of arterial
insufficiency on the lower limb including thin atrophic or hairless skin,
poor pedal pulses, diminished capillary refill, or hypertrophic deformed
Patients with stasis or lipdermatosclerosis are prone to bouts of
bacterial cellulitis, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or encapsulated
streptococci. Typically, stasis dermatitis develops slowly, over a week or
more. It is often bilateral. The onset of bacterial cellulitis is usually
abrupt, typically developing over 1 or 2 days. Bacterial cellulitis often
starts in one area and spreads to adjacent areas. Bacterial cellulitis is
unilateral. Both can present with fever and leukocytosis.
In a patient with stasis and cellulitis and the physician is uncertain
about whether bacterial cellulitis is present, the physician should consider
a trial of bed rest, leg elevation, and if there is fluid overload, diuresis.
If the cellulitis improves in 24-48 hours, antibacterial therapy and the
attendant adverse reactions can be avoided. If it is clear that bacterial
cellulitis has occurred, antimicrobial therapy should be given.
Upper respiratory infections include several common syndromes
including pharyngitis (see below) and bronchitis (see below). Most
are caused by viruses and there is no benefit from antimicrobial
therapy. If a patient presents with a "URI," consider specific
syndromes that do respond to antimicrobial therapy like herpes simplex
stomatitis or thrush. If no condition that benefits from antimicrobial
therapy is present, antimicrobials will almost certainly not help but
will likely select for antimicrobial resistance and may lead to other

Antimicrobials are not indicated for uncomplicated pancreatitis.
In cases of necrotizing pancreatitis without infection, antimicrobial
prophylaxis does not improve patient outcomes. Antimicrobials increase the risk
of fungal superinfection and should not be used.
Antimicrobials are indicated for cases with pancreatic abscess, infected
pancreatic pseudocyst, or infected necrotic pancreas (phlegmon). The diagnosis
of infection can be difficult and may require aspiration. Consultation with
Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases is encouraged.
In cases with necrosis, aspirate necrotic material (fine needle under CT or
ultrasound guidance) for smear and culture. Uninfected cases should not receive

Infection of salivary tissue is a relatively common disease. It is usually
caused by a stone in the parotid duct, dehydration, or a viral infection.
Sialolithiasis in elderly patients often leads to ductal obstruction and
secondary infection. Other predisposing factors for ductal occlusion include
dehydration, anticholinergic medications such as tricyclics and diphenhydramine,
general disability and trauma. Once culture results are available adjust
antimicrobial therapy based on specific etiologic organism.
For more information click on the link below
Suppurative Parotitis or Chronic Bacterial Parotitis Exacerbation Empiric
Suspect mumps parotitis if there is fever, malaise, earache and bilateral tender
swelling of the parotid glands. For mumps parotitis treat with warm compresses
and analgesics and maintain good hydration to prevent secondary bacterial
infection. Other viral causes of parotitis include influenza and enteroviruses.

Suppurative Parotitis. Acute bacterial parotitis affects primarily elderly,
malnourished, dehydrated or post-operative patients. Symptoms include fever,
toxicity, and tender swelling along the mandible with purulent drainage from the
parotid duct. Suppurative parotitis is usually unilateral whereas viral
parotitis is usually bilateral. Pain is intense and aggressive, analgesic
therapy is required. Progression of infection may lead to massive swelling of
the neck, respiratory obstruction, septicemia and osteomyelitis of adjacent
facial bones. Empiric antibiotics are required for coverage of Staphylococcus
aureus if bacterial, and surgical drainage is usually necessary.
Chronic Parotitis. Parotitis is recurrent with intermittent acute exacerbations.
Chronic, low-grade bacterial infection results in functional destruction of the
salivary gland. It may be confused with Sjogren's syndrome, a noninfectious
illness. Therapy includes systemic antibiotics. Parotidectomy may eventually be
required for patients with long-standing infection.
Viral Parotitis. Mumps parotitis is characterized by the rapid, painful swelling
of one or both parotid glands within 2 to 3 weeks after exposure to the mumps
virus. Mumps usually involves both parotid glands whereas bacterial parotitis is
unilateral. Other viral causes of parotitis include influenza and enteroviruses.
Mumps parotitis usually resolves spontaneously in 5 to 10 days. Provide
symptomatic relief of pain and fever and maintain hydration to prevent secondary
Wilson et al., Am Fam Physician. 2014, 89(11)882-888

> Perform in an ICU or similar setting.

lapse or the risk of allergic reactions increases.
> A history of Stevens Johnson syndrome, exfoliative dermatitis, or erythroderma
are nearly absolute contraindications to desensitization.

Pertussis is associated with persistent cough in adolescents and adults.
Immunity conferred by pertussis vaccine wanes after about 10 years. The first 1
to 2 weeks of disease resembles viral upper respiratory infection.  After this,
the characteristic cough with whoop is present for 1 to 6 weeks, followed by a
2 to 3 week period of gradual resolution.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to bacterial infection of the upper
female reproductive tract. Likely bacterial pathogens include Neisseria
gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, anaerobes, enteric Gram-negative rods, and
Streptococcus agalactiae. PID should be considered in sexually active women
with pelvic tenderness and signs of lower genital tract inflammation. Signs and
symptoms may be mild or non-specific, and providers should have a low threshold
to initiate treatment. All women who are diagnosed with acute PID should be
tested for N. gonorrohoeae, C. trachomatis, and HIV. Male sex partners of
patients with PID should be examined and treated (see below) if they had sexual
contact within the 60 days before onset of the patient's symptoms.
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, and degree of fever.

Contents.Text: Indications for primary prophylaxis of P. jirovecii include:
1) HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 count <200 cells/microliter
2) Hematopoietic or organ transplantation patients during immunosuppression
3) Patients receiving Alemtuzumab, temozolomide or fludarabine
4) Patients receiving >/= 20mg equivalent of prednisone per day for over 1 month
5) Patients with acute lymphocytic leukemia, rheumatologic disease receiving
immunosuppressive therapy and certain primary immunodeficiencies (e.g. severe
combined immunodeficiency, idiopathic CD4 T-lymphocytopenia, hyper-IgM
Dose and duration of prophylaxis varies with the indication. Please contact
Infectious Diseases or Hematology/Oncology for more information.
Prophylaxis should be discontinued when host defenses are restored. In persons
with AIDS on highly active antiretroviral therapy, Prophylaxis should be
discontinued when the CD4 cell concentrations remain over 200 cells/microliter
for 3-6 months in patients, except that prophylaxis should be continued for
life in those who have had P. jirovecii disease.

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU BACTEREMIA COAG NEG STAPH
ORZID2 GMENU INTRAVAS CATH COAG-NEG STAPH
Contents.Text: Treatment of CNS Infected Intravascular Catheters
BLOOD CULTURE POSITIVE FOR COAGULASE NEGATIVE STAPHYLOCOCCI (CNS)
CNS are the most common contaminants isolated from blood cultures. When CNS
isolated from blood cultures represent true bacteremia, the blood is usually
obtained from a patient with plastic or metal in the body. The most common
source of coagulase negative staphylococcal bacteremia is an infected
When CNS are isolated from blood, the physician should carefully assess the
patient to decide whether the isolation represents disease or colonization.
Colonization is more likely if a single bottle is positive or both bottles from
a single blood draw are positive. If multiple bottles are positive from separate
blood draws, it is more likely that the isolates reflect disease or colonization
of an intravascular device. Isolates from contaminated bottles often take
several days to become positive. If the patient has risk factors for true
coagulase negative staphylococcal bacteremia, catheter-related blood stream
infection and/or the patient is severely ill, antimicrobials should be given
(see below). If there is a plastic or metal prosthesis in the body, the
physician should evaluate the site for possible infection. If the isolates are
likely to represent contamination and the patient does not seem ill with CNS,
antimicrobial therapy would not be helpful and should not be given.
Mandell chapter: Staphylococcus epidermis and Other Coagulase-Negative
Mermel et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2009, 49

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ABX PREGNANCY RISK FACTORS

Contents.Text: Risk Factors for Antimicrobials During Pregnancy
Risk Factors (A, B, C, D, X) have been assigned to all drugs, based on the
level of risk the drug poses to the fetus.  Risk Factors are designed to
help the clinician quickly classify a drug for use during pregnancy.  They
do no refer to breastfeeding risk.  The definitions of the Risk Factors
are those used by the FDA.
A  Controlled studies show no risk
Adequate, well-controlled studies in pregnant women have
failed to demonstrate risk to the fetus.
B  No evidence of risk in humans
Either animal findings show risk (but human findings do not)
or, if no adequate human studies have been done, animal
C  Risk cannot be ruled out
Human studies are lacking and animal studies are either
positive for fetal risk or lacking as well.  However,
potential benefits my justify the potential risk.
Investigational or postmarketing data show risk to fetus.
Nevertheless, potential benefits may outweigh the risk.
Studies in animals or humans, or investigational or
postmarketing reports have shown fetal risk which clearly
outweighs any possible benefit to the patient.
Cefotetan, Cefoxitin, Ceftazidime, Cetriaxone, Cefuroxime, Cephalexin,

PATIENTS UNDERGOING PROCEDURES THAT INVOLVE INFECTED SKIN,
SKIN STRUCTURES, OR INFECTED MUSCULOSKELETAL TISSUE
A patient with an infection involving skin, skin structures, or infected
musculoskeletal tissue may need antimicrobial for treatment of this infection
(links provided below).  If so, the antimicrobial may also reduce the risk of
endocarditis in a person with a high risk cardiac lesion.  Under these
circumstances, ensure that antimicrobial concentrations in tissues are
therapeutic for the duration of the procedure.  If the patient is not
receiving systemic antimicrobial therapy for treatment of the infection,
consider giving one dose of an antimicrobial listed below for prevention of
endocarditis in a person with a high risk cardiac lesion.
Systemic treatment for infected skin, soft tissue, muscle bone or joint
Single dose prophylaxis in a person with a high risk cardiac lesion

Contents.Text: Wilson et al. Prevention of Infective Endocarditis: Circulation 2007
Wright et al. Antibiotic Prophylaxis in dermatologic Surgery: Advisory statement
Nishimura et al. Acc/Aha 2008 Guidelines Update on Valvular Heart Disease:
Hirschmann JV. When Antibiotics are Unnecessary. Dermatol Clin 2009.
Antibiotics are used to prevent infections in patients undergoing surgery in
certain well defined circumstances. They are used to prevent surgical site
infection or to prevent endocarditis in circumstances where the risk of
endocarditis is high. For many low-risk surgeries, the risks associated with
antibiotic use, which can be severe or cause death, outweigh the benefits. The
following recommendations have been approved by the MVAMC Dermatology and
Infectious Disease Services and are consistent with guidelines published by the
American Heart Association and Infectious Disease Society of America.
In general, antibiotics are used to prevent post-operative wound infection only
in clean-contaminated surgery. Most dermatological surgery involves "clean"
sites, and the risks of antibiotics outweigh potential benefits.  Antibiotics
are used to prevent endocarditic only during procedures likely to cause
bacteremia and only in patients with cardiac defects that place them at high
When they are used, prophylactic oral antimicrobial agents should be
administered 30-60 minutes before the first tissue manipulation or incision.
Antimicrobials should not be used to prevent infections in patients with
vascular grafts or orthopedic prostheses because the risk of bacteremia or
infection of these devices is tiny and antibiotics risks outweigh any
Antibiotics should be used to treat skin infections where infection is already
present at the time of surgery.
Suggested antibiotic prophylaxis regimens should be targeted against the typical
Table 1. High risk cardiac conditions for which antibiotic prophylaxis is
indicated for patients undergoing dermatologic surgery on infected skin or that
Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduits
Completely repaired congenital heart defects with prosthetic material or

Repaired CHD with residual defects at site or adjacent to site of prosthetic

Features of pyelonephritis include fever/other signs of systemic infection,
flank pain, costovertebral tenderness, and pelvic or perianal pain in men. Most
cases are caused by Escherichia coli. Resistant organisms, such as Enterococcus
and Pseudomonas, are more likely if the patient is elderly, has been in the
hospital for more than 48 hours, or received a course of antibiotics.
Obtain a urine culture, urine Gram-stain, and blood culture immediately to guide
Drugs active against enterococci (ampicillin, piperacillin) or staphylococci
needn't be used if Gram-negative bacilli predominate on the smear. Broad
spectrum antimicrobials are needed if patient is at risk of having a multi-drug
Judge severity of infection based on clinical signs and symptoms, including
blood pressure, pulse, mental status, white blood count, and degree of fever.
Oral regimens are preferred over IV if severity is mild or moderate and patient
can tolerate oral antibiotics. In patients with severe or persistent disease,
new renal failure, or suspected urinary obstruction, obtain a renal ultrasound
to rule out obstruction or other complicating condition. Consult urology if
When patients who require paraenteral therapy are afebrile, clinically stable,
and can take oral medication, convert to oral therapy based on the
identification and susceptibility of the isolate.

Infectious Disease or Pulmonary consult is strongly encouraged for patients who
do not respond to initial therapy.  If bacterial pneumonia is still considered
Decide whether a likely pathogen has been identified from respiratory secretions
or blood.  The clinician must decide whether any organisms identified on smear
or culture of respiratory tract secretions reflect disease, colonization, or
contamination based on clinical and microbiological information.
The quality of a respiratory secretion sample must be evaluated.  Sputum samples
with fewer than 25 polymorphonuclear leukocytes per high power field (hpf) are
unlikely to be from a site of bacterial infection unless the patient is
profoundly neutropenic.  Sputum samples with more than 10 epithelial cells/hpf
are likely to be contaminated with upper respiratory tract secretions.
In cases of bacterial pneumonia, a gram stain of a high quality respiratory
tract secretion usually contains 3+ or 4+ of bacteria with morphology and
staining characteristics consistent with the pathogen.  Culture of the
respiratory tract secretion indicates the species and susceptibilities of the
Step 3.  Adjust or discontinue antimicrobial therapy
Decide whether to continue, modify, or discontinue antimicrobials.  If an
organism likely to be a respiratory pathogen is isolated from a patient thought
to have bacterial pneumonia, adjust therapy if necessary to treat this pathogen.
If the patient does not have convincing evidence for bacterial pneumonia and/or
a likely pathogen has not been isolated from respiratory secretions then stop

REACTIVATION OF PRIMARY INFECTION (ZOSTER OR SHINGLES)
Zoster represents reactivation of varicella-zoster virus. After primary
infection, virus remains latent in the sensory dorsal root ganglia.
Reactivation syndrome is characterized by painful, unilateral, vesicular,
Vaccinate all adults greater than or equal to 50 years of age with the
recombinant zoster vaccine regardless of past episode or receipt of the live
Give recombinant zoster vaccine x2, 2nd dose 2-6 months after the first
Treatment is not beneficial, none is recommended.
Treatment with antivirals can shorten duration of pain and rash in patients over
50 years old. Treatment must be started within 72 hours of onset.
There is evidence that addition of corticosteroids to antiviral
therapy decreases pain and duration of rash and improves quality of life
modestly during the acute shingles episode. Corticosteroids do not decrease the
incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia. Some authorities recommend addition of
corticosteroid therapy to antiviral therapy for patients over age 50 years.
Corticosteroids are not recommended for patients at greater risk for steroid
toxicities (e.g., insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, hypertension, peptic
ulcer disease) or for immunocompromised patients.
Immunocompromised patients at increased risk for complications of VZV disease
include: patients with malignancy, current immunosuppressive therapy, or HIV
infection. Treatment with antivirals shortens duration of symptoms and reduces
incidence of complications. In immunocompromised patients, treatment is
recommended to be started at any point during an active infection.

SECONDARY PERITONITIS, INTRAABDOMINAL ABSCESS, INTRAPERITONEAL ABSCESS
Secondary peritonitis occurs after spillage of colonic flora into the peritoneum
due to ruptured viscus, perforated appendicitis, gastrointestinal trauma, or
Intraperitoneal or intraabdominal abscess can complicate secondary or primary
peritonitis. Abscess location is generally related to primary disease site.
CT or US-guided percutaneous or surgical drainage should be considered in all
cases for diagnostic confirmation, microbiologic evaluation, and therapy.
After adequate drainage, 4 days of antibiotic coverage is indicated, with
duration in part based on resolution of fever, leukocytosis, ileus severity of
infection, and additional indicators of clinical response. Inadequately drained
abscess with residual fluid may require prolonged therapy with follow-up imaging
Treatment of mild to moderate disease
Treatment of severe disease (typically necessitating ICU admission)
Step down treatment after initial intravenous antibiotic treatment in patients
who can tolerate oral therapy. Base selection on culture results.

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX PEP OCCUPATIONAL EXPOSURE
Contents.DisplayText: POST EXPOSURE BLOOD BODY FLUIDS PROPHYLAXIS FOR OCCUPATIONAL EXPOSURE
Contents.Text: HIV Post-Exposure Prophylaxis Occupational (Blood/Body Fluids) Outpatient
A diagnosis of a sexually transmitted infection can suggest sexual activity
that could result in HIV exposure. Recommendation is for the provider to
discuss with the patient Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) to reduce risk of
HIV acquisition.  If the patient is interested, the provider should place a
consult to MRTC clinic for further discussion and evaluation for PrEP.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (or PrEP) is a way for people who do not have
HIV but who are at high risk of getting HIV to prevent HIV infection by
taking a pill every day. When someone is exposed to HIV through sex or
injection drug use, these medicines can work to keep the virus from
When taken daily, PrEP is highly effective for preventing HIV. Studies
have shown that PrEP reduces the risk of getting HIV from sex by about
99% when taken daily. PrEP is much less effective if not taken consistently.
As PrEP only protects against HIV, condoms are important for the protection
against other STIs. Condoms are also an important prevention strategy
if PrEP is not taken consistently.

-Sotrovimab EUA does NOT include post-exposure prophylaxis.

ALL of the following criteria must be met for a patient to receive:
1) Patient has a laboratory-confirmed diagnosis of mild to moderate COVID-19.
2) Patient is not hospitalized due to COVID-19.
Note: patient may be hospitalized for some other reason.
3) Patient does NOT require oxygen therapy for COVID-19.
For patients on chronic oxygen therapy: patient does NOT require an
increase in baseline oxygen flow rate due to COVID-19.
4) Administration will begin within 7 days of symptom onset.
5) Patient does not have known hypersensitivity to sotrovimab or components.
6) Patient has at least one risk factor for progression to severe disease

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX SPLENECTOMY DAILY ANTIBIOTICS

Contents.Text: Functional or Anatomical Asplenia Vaccine & Antibiotic Prophylaxis Guideline
Following a splenectomy there is considerably increased risk of developing
septicemia from invasive encapsulated organisms, namely Streptococcus pneumonia,
Haemophilus inluenza type b and meningococcus. Key measures to prevent
such infections include education, vaccination, prophylactic antimicrobial
therapy in selected patients, and early empirical therapy for febrile
epsisodes. It is critically important to educate patients regarding the
lifelong risk of postsplenectomy sepsis, the importance of vaccinations,
and the need for urgent action in response to a febrile episode.
Management of an Episode of Fever in an Asplenic Patient
Routine vaccines should be up to date including influenza, Tdap, Zoster,
HPV, MMR, Varicella. See CDSS Immunization section to order.
Ideally splenectomy vaccinations should be given 10 to 12 weeks before
elective splenectomy.  Where this is not possible they can be given up to
two weeks before or at least two weeks post-splenectomy.
Use of Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Asplenia:
Use of antibiotic prophylaxis, in addition to vaccination, further reduces
the risk of infection and poor outcomes.
Daily Antibiotic Prophylaxis: (in addition to emergency supply)
Emergency Supply Empiric Abx for Fever or Other Signs of Systemic Infection:

SBP is infection of the peritoneal cavity in the absence of apparent trauma or
other obvious cause. SBP occurs primarily in people with end-stage liver disease
and ascites. The diagnosis is made when a peritoneal fluid sample has >/= 250
polymorphonuclear leukocyte cells per microliter, or when bacterial pathogens
Long-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients who experience a first
episode of SBP. Short-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients with
variceal bleeding, or for patients who have low-protein refractory ascites (<1
gm albumin/dl ascitic fluid). Some give long-term antimicrobials to patients
with low-protein refractory ascites. Consult Gastroenterology for more

Contents.Item: ORZ SET ABX OP CHLORHEXIDINE MUPIROCIN DECOLONIZATION
Contents.DisplayText: Mupirocin 2% ointment topically BID ($) [M] <AND> chlorhexidine 4% liquid
Contents.Text: Mupirocin 2% ointment topically BID ($) [M] <AND> chlorhexidine 4% liquid
From 10% to 40% of adults are colonized with Staphylococcus aureus, and the
anterior nares is the most common site of colonization. The great majority of
people never have disease with S. aureus, but a tiny fraction of people develop
clinical infections with the S. aureus that has colonized their skin or anterior
nares. Steps to decolonize the skin and anterior nares can transiently diminish
or eradicate S. aureus colonization and can prevent post-operative wound
infection in certain high-risk circumstances. For people who have other forms
of recurrent S. aureus disease, not associated with an operation, results with
decolonization have been disappointing, and decolonization is not routinely
recommended. Colonization typically reappears in most patients within a few
days or weeks after decolonization has been attempted. Clinicians occasionlly
wish to attempt decolonization for patients with frequent, troublesome
recurrences. The procedure here is one of several that have been studied, but
none have been particularly effective over the long run.
Consultation with Infectious Diseases is recommended.
topically q24h nursing text order ($) [M] for 5 days

Stasis dermatitis is a common condition that is often confused with
bacterial cellulitis. Stasis dermatitis does not benefit from antimicrobial
therapy. It is important to distinguish between the two. The provider
should be mindful of the fact that bacterial cellulitis can occur on skin
with underlying stasis dermatitis. (See link below for bacterial cellulitis)
Common risk factors for venous stasis include advancing age, family
history of venous disease, increased body mass index, smoking, a history of
trauma, prior venous thrombosis and pregnancy. Chronic venous disease and
arterial vascular disease have some common risk factors (eg, smoking,
obesity) and pathophysiological processes. The most common symptoms reported
by patients with chronic venous disease are limb discomfort (tired, heavy
legs), pain, and limb swelling. Swelling is often worse with prolonged
standing and improves with leg elevation and walking. The skin of the
anterior surfaces of the lower legs often has brown or blue-grey
People with venous stasis are prone to develop stasis dermatitis which
is one of the most common and earliest dermatologic signs of chronic venous
insufficiency. Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory process that presents as
an eczematous rash characterized by itching, erythema, scaling, weeping,
erosions, and crusting. Longstanding cases may develop lipodermatosclerosis
a fibrosing panniculitis of the subcutaneous tissue. Lipodermatosclerosis
typically starts with a firm area of induration at the medial ankle. As the
process progresses, the entire leg lower leg can become involved with
extension up to the mid leg in more advanced cases. The skin overlying the
panniculitis is typically heavily pigmented and bound down to the
subcutaneous tissues. Brawny edema above the fibrotic area and on the foot
below is seen in advanced cases. Leukocytosis and fever are common in people
Chronic venous disease is the most common cause of leg ulcers. They
are usually found low on the medial ankle over a perforating vein, or along
the course of the great or small saphenous veins. They occur more proximally
if precipitated by trauma. Venous ulcers are not found on the forefoot or
above the level of the knee. Venous ulcers can be multiple or single, and
can be exquisitely tender, shallow, exudative and have a granulation base.
The ulcer borders are usually irregular but not undermined. They can extend
circumferentially around the leg if left untreated.
Arterial ulcers are typically painful, and punched out or stellate. The
surrounding skin is red and taut. Some arterial ulcers are pale - others have
a black or yellow eschar. They are often associated with trauma and commonly
occur on the foot over pressure points. There may be other signs of arterial
insufficiency on the lower limb including thin atrophic or hairless skin,
poor pedal pulses, diminished capillary refill, or hypertrophic deformed
Patients with stasis or lipodermatosclerosis are prone to bouts of
bacterial cellulitis, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or encapsulated
streptococci. Typically, stasis dermatitis develops slowly, over a week or
more. It is often bilateral. The onset of bacterial cellulitis is usually
abrupt, typically developing over 1 or 2 days. Bacterial cellulitis often
starts in one area and spreads to adjacent areas. Bacterial cellulitis is
unilateral. Both can present with fever and leukocytosis.
In a patient with stasis and cellulitis and the physician is uncertain
about whether bacterial cellulitis is present, the physician should consider
a trial of bed rest, leg elevation, and if there is fluid overload, diuresis
If the cellulitis improves in 24-48 hours, antibacterial therapy and the
attendant adverse reactions can be avoided. If it is clear that bacterial
cellulitis has occurred, antimicrobial therapy should be given.
Stevens et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2014, 59(2): e10-52

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the spirochete Treponema
pallidum that can manifest as a variety of signs or symptoms. Primary syphilis
typically consists of painless ulcers or chancre at the site of infection with
regional adenopathy. Secondary syphilis often includes a skin rash (disseminated
and/or including the palms and soles), fever, malaise, mucocutaneous lesions and
lymphadenopathy. Tertiary syphilis includes those with cardiovascular or
Latent syphilis is a period of disease when a patient does not have symptoms but
is found to be infected through serologic testing. Early latent syphilis refers
to latent syphilis acquired within the preceding year and late latent syphilis
refers to all other cases of latent syphilis. Neurosyphilis can occur at any
stage of syphilis with early manifestations (e.g. meningitis, stroke, vision or
hearing loss) occurring within the first months to years of infection and late
manifestations (e.g. dementia, tabes dorsalis) occurring after 10-30 years.
A presumptive diagnosis is made through use of a nontreponemal or serologic
test (i.e. rapid plasma reagin [RPR]) and a treponemal test (i.e. fluorescent
treponemal antibody absorbed [FTA-ABS]). Direct methods through darkfield
microscopy and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) must be used for definitive
diagnosis since T. pallidum cannot be cultured.
Persons with sexual contact with a person with primary, secondary or early
latent syphilis within the last 90 days should be presumptively treated even if
Alternative for patients with severe penicillin allergy who are not pregnant

Contents.Text: TOCILIZUMAB (IL- 6 RECEPTOR BLOCKER) FOR TREATMENT OF COVID-19
In hospitalized patients with COVID-19 who are hypoxic and have evidence of
systemic inflammation, tocilizumab improved mortality. These benefits were seen
regardless of the level of respiratory support and were additional to the
The FIRST dose of tocilizumab DOES NOT require ID approval. Patient must meet
all inclusion criteria. If any questions, please page ID on call. Due to
current shortage, and uncertainty of benefit of second dose, would
o Clinical evidence of progressive COVID-19 (supplemental oxygen, high-flow
oxygen, or noninvasive or invasive ventilation) <AND>
o Patient does not have a known hypersensitivity to tocilizumab
o Counseling is provided and documented in the electronic health record per EUA.
The provider has communicated with the patient/caregiver regarding
information contained in the "Fact Sheet for Patients". The patient/
caregiver has been given the Fact sheet, informed that the drugs are
unapproved drugs that are authorized for use under an EUA, given information
on alternatives and their risks and benefits, and the patient/caregiver
has the right to refuse or accept. (See top of page for Fact Sheet)
o Current documented or suspected bacterial or fungal infection
o ANC < 1000/mm3, platelet count < 50,000/mm3, ALT/AST> 10x ULN
If all the above inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria, the 1st
dose of tocilizumab may be ordered below based on patient's weight.
If the patient's condition has not improved in 12-24 hours after receiving the
1st dose, a second dose may be considered in select patients. Please page ID fo

Uncomplicated cystitis is defined as symptomatic bladder inflammation caused by
bacterial infections in people with structurally and neurogenically normal
urinary tract. Symptoms usually include dysuria, lower abdominal pain, and
urgency. Most cases of uncomplicated cystitis occur in pre-menopausal,
non-pregnant, sexually active young women and is commonly associated with
Enterobacteriaceae (e.g. E. coli and Klebsiella sp.) and occasionally S.
Cystitis is considered complicated when it occurs in pregnant women, people
with abnormalities of the urinary tract, immunocompromised individuals and those
who have persistent, recurrent, or relapsed infections, or treatment failure are
considered complicated. Diagnosis and treatment of complicated cystitis is
The presence of pyuria (>7 wbc/hpf) or positive leukocyte esterase, urine
nitrate, or urine bacteria is not a sufficient indication for antibiotic
treatment. Asymptomatic bacteriuria occurs in patients who have bacteria in the
urine with no symptoms of cystitis, and with few exceptions, should not be
treated. Diagnosis and treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria is further
The prevalence of antimicrobial resistance among bacteria associated with
uncomplicated cystitis has increased. A urine culture should be considered in a
patient who has had substantial involvement with healthcare or exposure to
antimicrobials. If a patient fails to respond to therapy, a urine culture should
For women with recurrent uncomplicated cystitis (2 episodes in 6 months or 3 or
more episodes in 12 months), suppressive therapy is indicated after infection is
eradicated and non-antimicrobial prevention methods, such as increased fluid
intake and avoiding spermicide, are considered. Consider consulting Women's
*Avoid trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole in the first and third trimesters

Contents.Text: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Cystitis refers to infection of the urinary bladder, but inflammation often
extends into the urethra. Typical symptoms and signs include dysuria, increased
urinary frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.
Most cases of uncomplicated cystitis occur in pre-menopausal, non-pregnant,
Most cases of complicated cystitis are associated with Escherichia coli, but
more resistant pathogens occur, including the Gram-positive pathogens
staphylococci and enterococci. Urine culture should be obtained before
Cystitis is considered complicated when one or more of the following is present
> Structural abnormalities (e.g. presence of obstruction, catheter or
> Metabolic abnormalities that reduce local host defenses (e.g. diabetes,
> Treatment failure or relapse or recurrence of infection
When a patient presents with symptoms of cystitis, urinalysis should be
performed to check for the presence of white blood cells. Increased numbers of
leukocytes (usually >25) in the presence of cystitis symptoms indicates
inflammation and thus cystitis. The bacterial etiology is so predictable that
urine culture is unnecessary and empirical treatment is indicated. The
clinical significance of pyuria in the absence of cystitis symptoms is unclear.
Antimicrobial therapy is not indicated for pyuria in the absence of symptoms.

Bacterial vaginosis is the most common form of vaginitis. Normal hydrogen
peroxide and lactic acid producing vaginal flora, including Lactobacillus
species, is reduced and high concentrations of anaerobic bacterial pathogens are
present. Pathogenic bacteria commonly include Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma
hominis, Nobiluncus, Prevotella and other Gram-negative anaerobes.
Vaginal pH should be measured, and the specimen should be examined under the
microscope for identification of clue cells (epithelial cell coated with
bacteria). In bacterial vaginosis the vaginal pH is high (> 4.5), the discharge
is homogenous and gray-white, and the specimen has a positive amine or whiff
test characterized by a fishy odor before or after addition of 10% KOH.
Bacterial vaginosis nucleic acid amplification tests are available for common
pathogens to aide in identification of pathogen(s).
Bacterial vaginosis may be transmitted sexually. Patients at risk of sexually
transmitted infections should be assessed for treatment.
Up-to-Date article: Bacterial vaginosis: Clinical manifestations and diagnosis
Workowski et al., MMWR Recomm Rep, 2021, 70(4)1-187

Contents.Text: Drug-Drug Interactions between Antimicrobials and Warfarin:
Several antimicrobials will affect metabolism or the affect of warfarin
on a patient's clotting function.  If possible, avoid using an
antimicrobial with a significant interaction with warfarin.  If you
decide that an antimicrobial that interacts with warfarin is needed or
you stop an antimicrobial that could interact with warfarin, you should
determine the INR more frequently than usual and adjust dosage
accordingly.  Instruct patients to inform their primary warfarin
provider whenever an antimicrobial is prescribed for them.
Antimicrobials can alter warfarin's anticoagulant effect by decreasing
intestinal synthesis or absorption of vitamin K or by affecting
distribution or metabolism of the vitamin.  Some antimicrobials increase
Antimicrobials can decrease the rate of warfarin absorption, compete
with warfarin at sites of warfarin metabolism, induce warfarin metabolic
enzymes, or inhibit the function or synthesis warfarin metabolic
enzymes.  Some antimicrobials displace warfarin from protein binding sites.

Severe signs or symptoms of high fever (>/= 102 degrees Fahrenheit, >/= 39
degrees Celsius) and purulent nasal discharge for 3-4 consecutive days or facial
pain lasting for at least 3-4 consecutive days at the beginning of illness.

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Chemotherapy with purine analogues such as fludarabine, cladribine, or
pentostatin results in major cellular-immunodeficiency that may outlast the
exposure by months and enhances the risk for viral infections.
Recommend antiviral prophylaxis for patients treated with purine analogues,
if at least one of the following risk factors is present:
e) Prolonged Mild or Moderate Neutropenia: Mild<1000 Neutrophils /
µL (Grade III neutropenia) OR Moderate: <500 Neutrophils/µL
Duration: Antiviral prophylaxis should be initiated in the first week of
therapy and continued until 2 months after completion of therapy.
Alemtuzumab is a potent reactivator of latent intracellular pathogens,
including CMV. Chemotherapy with alemtuzumab results in major cellular-
immunodeficiency that may outlast the exposure by months and enhances the
risk for viral infections. The risk of viral disease increases with the
intensity and duration of functional T-cell suppression experienced with
Duration: Initiate antiviral prophylaxis with alemtuzumab therapy and
continue therapy for at least 2 months after last dose or until CD4 counts
are greater than or equal to 200 cells/ul, whichever is later.
Taplitz RA Journal of Clinical Oncology 2018, 36:3043
Mandel Chapter: Prophylaxis and Empirical Therapy of Infection in

PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Prophylaxis for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) or Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
Prophylaxis for Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses
Yearly influenza vaccination with inactivated vaccine is recommended for all
patients receiving chemotherapy for malignancy and all family and household
Optimal timing of vaccination for patients being treated for cancer is not
established, but serologic responses may be best between chemotherapy cycles
(greater than 7 days after the last treatment) or greater than 2 weeks
Patients with active malignant disease are at higher risk for upper
respiratory infections due to influenza, parainfluenza or respiratory
syncytial virus (RSV). Although response to vaccination with the attenuated
influenza vaccine in patients on chemotherapy is variable, ranging
from 24-75%, immnunoprophylaxis with the influenza vaccine is recommended for
patients with active malignant disease or chemotherapy, lymphoproliferative
disease, or multiple myeloma. In areas and seasons where influenza is
endemic, chemoprophylaxis can be considered in addition to vaccination in
exposed patients with a high risk of influenza complications.
Prophylaxis and monitoring for CMV reactivation is not recommended unless the
patient has received an allogeneic HSCT. Usually the recommendations for
surveillance and prophylaxis of CMV infections from the institution
performing the HSCT will be followed.
Reactivation of chronic hepatitis B in patients undergoing immunosuppressive
or antineoplastic treatment is a severe complication. Patients with positive
HBsAg, chronic hepatitis B infection, or a previous episode of HBV
reactivation who will receive immunosuppressive therapy should receive
Recommend routine testing for Hepatitis B prior to initiating Rituximab

Contents.Text: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) or Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Viral infections reactivate in a small percentage of people with malignancy.
Most viral infections in patients with hematologic malignancies or solid
tumors result from reactivation of asymptomatic latent infections,
predominantly of herpes viruses, including herpes simplex virus (HSV),
varicella zoster virus (VZV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Exogenous
respiratory tract infections caused by influenza, parainfluenza
or respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) are less common.
The main risk factor for clinically relevant reactivation is profound
disruption of cellular immune response, usually due to chemotherapy.
The duration and severity of neutropenia are of lesser importance.
The risk of viral disease increases with the intensity and duration
of functional T-cell suppression. Patients receiving conventionally
dosed chemotherapy regimens for solid tumors experience no major
T-cell suppression and do not have a higher incidence of

Name: ORZID2 GMENU ANTIVIRAL TYPE OF MALIGNANCY

Contents.Item: PSJZID ACYCLOVIR 800 MG PO BID PROPHYLAXIS

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Solid tumors do not significantly compromise the cellular immune system.
Therefore, patients are at low risk for opportunistic viral infections.
Documented invasive viral infections are very rare. Coincidental
mucocutaneous infections by herpes simplex are easily treated and do not
result in life-threatening invasive infections. Reactivation of
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is rarely observed.
In patients with acute leukemia, treatment is highly aggressive and consists
of a combination of various cytotoxic agents administered in sequential
cycles as induction, consolidation and maintenance therapy. Persistent, i.e.
>10 days and profound neutropenia (<500 neutrophils) regularly occurs and
correlates with the risk of developing fever and infections. Almost all viral
infections during neutropenia constitute reactivations of herpes viruses.
None of the available studies demonstrated an effect of antiviral prophylaxis
on the initiation of antibiotic treatment, number of febrile days, duration
of antibiotic treatment, and onset of opportunistic infections. Therefore, no
recommendation for antiviral prophylaxis in patients with acute leukemia can
Patients undergoing leukemia induction therapy should receive prophylaxis.
Rituximab is a monoclonal anti-CD-20 antibody used for treatment of
lymphomas. It leads to a profound depletion of circulating B-cells. B-cells
recover usually within 3-6 months after treatment. Prolonged administration
of rituximab (e.g., maintenance treatment >12 months) may result in a
significant decrease of levels of immunoglobulin M. Parvovirus B19 and JC-
papovavirus infections have been reported with maintenance rituximab therapy,
but drugs that would prevent these infections are not available. There is no
substantial increase in risk of reactivation of herpes viruses (including
Recommend routine testing for Hepatitis B virus prior to initiating Rituximab
Mandel Chapter: Prophylaxis and Empirical Therapy of Infection in
Sandherr,M et al, Annals of Oncology 17: 1051-1059, 2006

APPROACH TO FOOT ULCER WITH INFECTION
Whenever possible, material should be obtained for Gram stain and culture.
Specimens from deep ulcer biopsy, aspiration, or bone biopsy are superior to
wound swab or drainage.  Pathogen identification is especially important because
therapy is often given for weeks.
While foot ulcers in patients with diabetes typically have many bacterial
species on the surface, disease is usually caused by only one or two.  When
Staphylococcus aureus is present in a surface culture, it is usually a pathogen
in the deeper tissues.  Therapy can usually be directed against the predominant
or virulent organisms found on surface cultures and need not be active against
every isolate.  To reduce uncertainty it is better to obtain deeper cultures.
Bacteria that are most likely to be responsible for invasive infection include
S. aureus, streptococci, enteric gram-negative bacilli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa,
and anaerobes typical of the human enteric flora.  When there is no evidence
that would direct therapy to any single organism, empirical therapy should be

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX SUPPURATIVE THROMBO EMP THERAPY

Contents.Text: The likelihood of colonization of an intravenous catheter increases with time,
increasing noticeably after 3 days. Patients whose catheters become colonized
may or may not develop local or systemic signs or symptoms. All types of
catheters are associated with risk of local and catheter-associated bacteremia.
Since central catheters are usually used for more days than peripheral
catheters, central catheters have a greater risk of catheter-associated
When catheter-related bacteremia is suspected, draw blood cultures from both the
catheter and a peripheral vein. Growth rate between the two cultures may be used
to determine if the source of bacteremia is likely catheter-associated. If the
catheter obtained culture's time to positivity is 2 hours or more before the
peripheral vein obtained culture's time to positivity, this suggests catheter-
associated infection. Sample any exudate at the catheter site for gram stain and
Suppurative thrombophlebitis presents with inflammation in and around a vein.
There may be local thrombosis and/or bacteremia. Cases may be life-threatening
For patients with catheter-associated bacteremia with virulent pathogens like
Staphylococcus aureus, gram-negative bacilli, or candida, catheter removal is
almost always necessary. For mild or moderate cases with less virulent
organisms like coagulase-negative staphylococci, antimicrobial therapy is
successful without catheter removal about half of the time. The decision about
whether to remove the catheter depends on severity of illness, the need for the
catheter, and how difficult catheter replacement would be.
For cases in which an infected catheter is not removed, the success rate is
improved when the infected catheter is filled with an antimicrobial solution
during periods when the catheter is not used. Consult Infectious Diseases or
In Staphylococcus aureus cases, document that bacteremia has cleared during
antimicrobial therapy. Infectious Disease consultation is required for all
For a patient whose blood cultures remain positive for more than 3 days or with
a catheter tunnel abscess or who has a prosthetic device, contact Infectious
Gaur et al., Clinical infectious diseases 2003, 37.4

Contents.Text: Brain abscess is a focal infection of the brain parenchyma. Symptoms often
include headache, fever, altered mental status, seizures, and focal neural
deficits. Pathogens vary based on primary site of infection and patient's immune
status. Bacteria cause most infections in immunocompetent patients whereas a
wider array of pathogens, including fungi, cause infection in immunocompromised
Streptococci are the most isolated pathogen, often isolated from mixed
infections. Bacteroides are also commonly isolated in mixed cultures. Enteric
gram-negative bacilli are typically isolated in patients with otitic foci,
bacteremia, or post-neurosurgery. Staphylococcus aureus is commonly isolated in
a pure culture and in patients with endocarditis or cranial trauma. Brain
abscess caused by Listeria and Nocardia may occur in patients who are
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be obtained in all patients with
suspected brain abscess for diagnosis and determining number of lesions. Prior
to beginning antimicrobial therapy, when possible, computed topographic (CT) -
guided aspiration or surgery should be performed to obtain abscess material for
Solitary brain abscesses usually result from the spread of focal ear, sinus, or
dental infection (contiguous source). Cases with multiple abscesses often result
from hematogenous spread from infections such as endocarditis, abdominal
Consult Neurosurgery, Neurology, and Infectious Disease
Empiric Treatment After Obtaining Abscess Sample, When Possible
When infectious organism is identified, adjust antimicrobials to optimize
Brouwer et al. N Engl J Med, 2014, 371(5)447-56

Azithromycin for Prevention of Exacerbations in Advanced COPD
Daily azithromycin prevents chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
exacerbations in people with advanced COPD (Albert et al, see below).
Of note, in the study there was no benefit in the most severely ill
subgroup that was on the most pulmonary medications.  People
with frequent exacerbations have more doctor visits and hospitalizations than
people with fewer or no exacerbations.  Frequent exacerbations are associated
with rapid decline in lung function and quality of life and increased risk of
To receive daily azithromycin, patients must meet the following criteria and
receive approval from pulmonary service.  The evidence that benefits of daily
azithromycin outweigh risks is limited to people who meet the following
*Clinical diagnosis of COPD (>= 10 pack-years cigarette smoking, a ratio of
postbronchodilator forced expiratory volume in 1 second [FEV1] to forced
vital capacity of <70%, and a postbronchodilator FEV1 of <80% of the
*Were either using continuous supplemental oxygen or had received systemic
*Had gone to an emergency room or had been hospitalized for an acute
*Use of medications that are associated with torsades de pointes (with the
*Use of medications that prolong the QTc interval
If, after trying all of the standard treatments, patients are still having
acute exacerbations of COPD, long-term antibiotic treatment with Azithromycin
Note: Guidelines for COPD can be found on the CPRS Tools Menu.
If the patient meets the criteria and is willing to have audiometric testing
and an electrocardiogram, please place a Pulmonary Consult for long-term
Azithromycin therapy for the prevention of exacerbations of COPD.

Unlike other CNS, S. lugdunensis can cause severe disease like S. aureus. Refer
to Bacteremia Associated S. lugdunensis page for treatment.

likely to be pathogens in patients with a prosthetic device. Contact Infectious
For patients with catheter-related bacteremia or those with suspected

Surgical prophylaxis is indicated for open procedures and high risk
laparoscopic procedures.  Additional doses should not be given after
incisions are closed. Surgical prophylaxis is not indicated in elective
The risk of infectious complications after laparoscopic cholecystectomy is
increased after emergent procedures, procedures lasting more than 120 minutes,
intraoperative gall bladder rupture or bile spillage, conversion from
laparoscopic to open cholecystectomy, and insertion of a prosthetic device.
The risk is increased in patients who have had an episode of colic or a
biliary procedure within 30 days before the procedure, patients with acute
cholecystitis or jaundice, patients with a nonfunctional gallbladder, patients
with immunosuppression, pregnancy, diabetes, age greater than 70 years, or
American Society of Anesthesiologists classification of 3 or greater.
If one of these risk factors exists, prophylaxis is indicated for laparoscopic
cholecystectomy.  If there is a substantial likelihood that one of these risk
factors will develop during a procedure, the surgeon may elect to order
If no antimicrobial prophylaxis recommended, select below:

PNEUMONIA ACQUIRED IN A NURSING HOME SETTING
Treatment for nursing home resident ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL
Pneumonia in debilitated or chronically ill residents of nursing homes and
other long-term care facilities should be treated following recommendations for
hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).  Individual patients with conditions
that predispose to a single or narrow set of pathogens should receive more
targeted therapy.  For example, long-term dialysis is a risk for methicillin-
resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)infection but does not necessarily
predispose patients to infection with other HAP pathogens, like Pseudomonas
aeruginosa or Acinetobacer species.  Patients with chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease are at greater risk for infection with Pseudomonas spp. but
not MRSA.  Consult with infectious diseases or pulmonary services for more
Treatment for a debilitated or chronically ill resident of a nursing home:
Treatment for a nursing home resident who is NOT debilitated or chronically ill
po once on day 1, then 250 mg PO QDAY for 4 days ($) [M]

COMMUNITY-ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA (CAP) TREATED IN AN INPATIENT SETTING
Be sure of the diagnosis.  Careful reviews have shown that over half of
people treated for community-acquired pneumonia do not in fact have
pneumonia.  Pneumonia is likely in persons with 3 or more signs or symptoms
including a) new infiltrate (or, no prior film for comparison) b) new
crackles, egophony, or dullness c) pleuritic pain, d) fever and/or chills
e) leukocytosis f) cough g) purulent sputum and h) new or worsened dyspnea
or tachypnea, and no likely alternative explanation for the presentation.
Common alternative explanations include heart failure, thromboembolic
disease, COPD exacerbation, viral pneumonitis, aspiration pneumonitis, or
tumor. Most of the latter conditions do NOT benefit from antimicrobials.
Pharmacological therapy of community-acquired pneumonia in inpatients
should include 1 or 2 antimicrobial(s) and corticosteroids (Siemieniuk, et
al, 2015). Corticosteroid therapy decreases the risk of death, decreases
the need for ventilation and ICU admission, and shortens length of stay.
Corticosteroid therapy is likely to increase blood glucose concentrations
Recommendation for duration of antibiotic therapy for CAP:
Patients with CAP should be treated for a minimum of 5 days, should be
afebrile for 48-72 hours, and should have no more than 1 CAP-
associated sign of clinical instability before discontinuation
Temperature less than/equal to 100 degrees F
Heart rate less than/equal to 100 beats/minute
Respiratory rate less than/equal to 24 breaths/minute
Systolic blood pressure greater than/equal to 90 mm Hg
Arterial oxygen saturation greater than/equal to 90% --OR--
PO2 greater than/equal to 60 mm Hg on room air
Treatment on MEDICAL WARD (not intensive care)
on day 1, then 250 mg PO Q24H for 4 days ($) [M]  < OR >
Most patients respond in 3-5 days and treatment should ordinarily last 5-7
days. Risk factors indicating that pseudomonas is a possible cause of
community-acquired pneumonia include severe structural lung disease
(e.g. bronchiectasis), recent antibiotic therapy, or recent stay in a hospital.
If community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is
suspected (e.g., post influenza, injection drug user,Gram positive cocci in
clusters on Gram stain), add antibiotic to cover MRSA. (see below)
If Pseudomonas is NOT a likely pathogen
on day 1, then 250 mg PO Q24H ($) [M]
on day 1, then 250 mg IV Q24H ($) [M]
If Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a consideration (e.g. chronic or structural
lung disease, recent antibiotic therapy, recent hospitalization)
If community MRSA is suspected (e.g., post-influenza, injection drug user,
Gram positive cocci in clusters on Gram stain) ADD MRSA coverage

Contents.Text: SEVERE Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP) Treated in Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
Criteria for Defining SEVERE Community-acquired Pneumonia
Validated definition includes either one major or three or more minor criteria
Septic shock with need for vasopressors
Respiratory rate greater than or equal to 30 breaths/minute
PaO2/FiO2 ratio less than or equal to 250
Uremia (blood urea nitrogen level greater than 20 mg/dl)
*Due to infection alone (i.e., not chemotherapy induced)
Hypothermia (core temperature less than 36 degrees C)
Recommendation for duration of antibiotic therapy for CAP:
Patients with CAP should be treated for a minimum of 5 days, should be
afebrile for 48-72 hours, and should have no more than 1 CAP-
associated sign of clinical instability before discontinuation
Temperature less than/equal to 100 degrees F
Heart rate less than/equal to 100 beats/minute
Respiratory rate less than/equal to 24 breaths/minute
Systolic blood pressure greater than/equal to 90 mm Hg
Arterial oxygen saturation greater than/equal to 90% --OR--
PO2 greater than/equal to 60 mm Hg on room air
Stepdown empiric treatment for CAP (Intravenous to Oral conversion)
(Specific therapy should be guided by culture results.)
Recommend blood and lower respiratory tract specimen cultures for all patients

Cat-scratch disease occurs when a cat infected with Bartonella henselae
scratches or bites a person or licks a person's open wound.  A local pustule
develops followed by lymphadenopathy, typically on the same side of the body as
Infections associated with other pathogens such as Francisella tularemia,
Coxiella burnetiid and other slow-growing bacteria may present with similar
symptoms.  Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.
About 10% of cases of cat-scratch disease present atypically with symptoms
involving the eye, nervous system, or lungs.  Consult Infectious Diseases in
Mandell chapter: Bartonella, including cat-scratch disease

CERVICITIS ASSOCIATED WITH SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES
The main diagnostic signs that characterize cervicitis are 1)women who present
with purulent or mucopurulent exudate in the endocervical canal or on an
endocervical swab specimen and 2)sustained endocervical bleeding induced by
gentle passage of cotton swab through the cervical os. One or both signs may be
Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis are the two most common sexually
transmitted cervicitis pathogens. Nucleic acid amplification tests for these
pathogens are more sensitive than culture and should be used for patients at
For patients who have recently been treated for cervicitis
When diagnosed with sexually transmitted cervicitis, the patient's sexual
partner(s) during the previous 60 days should be evaluated for sexually
transmitted infection. If diagnostic tests for the cause of cervicitis are not
feasible, therapy for both N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis should be given to
Initial treatment of patients and sex partners
Patients and partners are often infected with both N. gonorrhoeae and C.
trachomatis. Treat for both pathogens unless one is ruled out by lab test.
Treatment for N. gonorrhoaeae AND C. trachomatis

Diagnosis of chronic sinusitis is based on presence of at least 2 of the 4
cardinal signs/symptoms lasting >/= 12 weeks. In addition, diagnosis requires
objective evidence of mucosal inflammation using nasal endoscopy and/or CT
imaging. The initial therapy for chronic sinusitis is treatment with intranasal
corticosteroids and saline. For patients with severe nasal blockage by polyps,
treat with a short course of oral glucocorticoids. Reassess patient after 1 to 3
months of intranasal therapy or after completion of glucocorticoid therapy. If
signs/symptoms have not improved, consult surgery, ENT and Infectious Diseases
Acute exacerbations of chronic sinusitis can be caused by discontinuing medical
therapy, viral infections, allergens, noxious inhalants and bacterial or fungal
infections. Bacterial infections should be suspected when the patient has
increased signs/symptoms persisting for more than 10 days. Refer to Severe
Sinusitis recommendations for choice of antimicrobial therapy in these patients.
Repeated use of the same agent should be avoided to prevent promotion of drug
resistant bacteria or increased fungal colonization.
