Patients with reduced CMI include those with HIV/AIDS, hematologic malignancies,
cytotoxic chemotherapy, and congenital abnormalities.  Patients with cell-
mediated immune defects are more susceptible to infections from ubiquitous
microorganisms that do not usually cause infection in healthy patients.  The
specific organisms that are more likely to be associated with disease vary
depending on the specific type of immune defect present, but include:
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly Pneumocystis carinii), Mycobacterium avium,
Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Salmonella spp., Candida spp., Aspergillus spp.,
Toxoplasma gondii, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus,
These infectious diseases usually have a subacute or chronic presentation.  The
best approach in most circumstances is for the clinician to conduct a methodical
diagnostic workup to identify the specific pathogen and guide therapy.
Empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for patients with CMI defects who
present only with fever.  Contact Infectious Disease for more information.

Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology

If in the preceding two months the patient has taken a PPI or has been
hospitalized for three or more days, consider Clostridium difficile infection.
Bloody diarrhea can represent hemorrhagic colitis or dysentery. Antimicrobial
therapy and antimotility agents are not recommended in most patients with bloody
diarrhea due to an increased risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome when using these
agents. Obtain a stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing and reserve
antimicrobial and antimotility agent treatment until results are known. Enteric
pathogen PCR testing results are reported within 2 hours between 7am and 11pm.
For more information on when an antimicrobial is indicated or if the patient has
severe/life threatening diarrhea or is immunocompromised, contact Infectious
Empiric antimicrobial treatment for non-bloody severe acute diarrhea
Subacute or chronic (>/= 14 days of symptoms)
Primary treatment is hydration and electrolyte replacement. Empiric
antimicrobial therapy is not indicated. Investigate for the cause of diarrhea.
Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases involvement is encouraged.

Conjunctivitis is associated with viral or bacterial pathogens. Viral
conjunctivitis presents with watery discharge. Bacterial infections are more
likely to present with thick exudate and conjunctival injection. Allergic
conjunctivitis typically presents with stringy mucus. If there is pus
(hypopion), corneal involvement, possible bacterial conjunctivitis, or
Viral conjunctivitis is most commonly caused by adenovirus. It is self-limited
and antivirals provide no benefit. Symptomatic treatment with ophthalmic
antihistamine/decongestants and warm or cool compresses may relieve symptoms.
Bacterial conjunctivitis is most commonly associated with Staphylococcus aureus,
Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus spp., Moraxella catarrhalis,
Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria spp. or enteric gram-negative rods. It is
generally self-limited, but topical antimicrobials reduce duration of symptoms
and limit person-to-person spread of infection. If symptoms do not improve after
2 days of antimicrobial therapy, the patient should be seen by an
Treatment for severe cases of bacterial conjunctivitis involving suppuration or
Consult ophthalmology and begin topical antimicrobials.

Contents.Text: Azithromycin 500 mg PO x 1 ($8/day) on day 1, then 250 mg PO QDAY ($4/day)
Cat-scratch disease occurs when Bartonella henselae is inoculated from a cat
scratch or bite. A local pustule develops followed by lymphadenopathy,
typically on the same side of the body as the scratch or bite. Infections
associated with other pathogens such as Francisella tularemia, Coxiella
burnetti, and other slow-growing bacteria may present with similar symptoms.
Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.
About 10% of cases of cat-scratch disease present atypically with symptoms
involving the eye, nervous system, or lungs. Consult Infectious Diseases in
Manguina C et al. Bartonella: new and old. Infect Dis Clin N Amer 2000, 14: 1

Contents.Item: ORZ ADD MENU CARDIOLOGY CONSULT MENU REVISED

Contents.Text: Treatment for more serious disease (ie, SECOND or THIRD DEGREE
Lyme disease results from the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi from an
Ixodes spp. tick bite. Patients who display signs of illness or fever within 30
days of removing an attached tick should be evaluated for tick-borne illness.
In the upper Midwest these are Lyme disease, human anaplasmosis (formerly
granulocytic ehrlichiosis, HGE), and babesiosis. Patients who have been bitten
by an Ixodes spp. tick ("deer tick") but who do not display signs or symptoms of
infection should not be treated with antimicrobials unless they have been
exposed in an area with an extremely high risk of Lyme disease from tick bites.
In the U.S., these areas exist only in small foci in the mid-Atlantic states.
Preventive antimicrobial treatment may be beneficial in certain patients who
have been bitten while in endemic areas. Contact Infectious Diseases for more
Except for erythema migrans, Lyme disease is a complicated, difficult disease to
diagnose and treat. Infectious Diseases consultation is strongly encouraged.

Contents.Text: ERYTHEMA MIGRANS ASSOCIATED WITH LYME DISEASE
Erythema migrans is the first manifestation of Lyme disease in half of cases.
It is typically an erythematous circular rash with induration and central
clearing (although other patterns occur) and it usually develops at the site of
the bite and/or in one or more distant locations. The rash occurs 3 to 30 days
after the bite. Rashes with onset less than 3 days after a tick bite are not
A recent study showed that a 10 day course of antimicrobials is as effective as
a 21 day course in treating erythema migrans.

Scabies is transmitted by skin to skin contact. Outbreaks occur in nursing
homes, day care centers, and residential institutions. Scabies is highly
contagious and meticulous infection control is needed.
Treatment is a single application of permethrin cream. Some experts recommend a
second application 7-10 days after the first application if the patient is still
symptomatic or if live mites are found at that time. Contact Dermatology or
Treat family members and other close contacts to prevent spread and recurrence.

Contents.Text: "Mandell" chapter: The acutely ill patient with fever and rash
Staphylococcal scaleded skin syndrome (SSSS) presents with severe skin
blistering and exfoliation resulting from toxins produced by Staphylococcus
aureus. SSSS is usually found in children and rarely in older adults. Obtain
a skin biopsy to differentiate between SSSS and toxic epidermal necrolysis.
Initiate anti-staphylococcal therapy and obtain cultures and susceptibilities.
If cultures reveal methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), change
to nafcillin or cefazolin for better antimicrobial activity.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) can be associated with either staphylococci or
streptococci. Antimicrobial treatment and supportive care is urgent. Click one
of the links below for diagnostic criteria.
Treatment of Staphylococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome
Use vancomycin initially in case methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is
present. If cultures reveal methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus
(MSSA), change to nafcillin or cefazolin for better antimicrobial activity.

Contents.Text: CDC CRITERIA FOR DIAGNOSIS OF STAPHYLOCOCCAL TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME
fewer criteria are met if staphylococcal TSS seems likely.
These criteria were developed for epidemiological purposes. Treat cases when
Definite:  All 6 of the following criteria are met.
Probable:  Five of the 6 criteria are met.
Systolic blood pressure 90 mmHg, orthostatic drop in diastolic 15 mmHg,
Occurs 1 to 2 weeks after onset of illness and usually involving palms and
Multisystem involvement (3 or more of the following organ systems)
Vomiting or diarrhea at onset of illness
Severe myalgia or CPK elevation >2 times the normal upper limit
BUN or serum creatinine >2 times the normal upper limit, or pyuria (>5
Bilirubin or transaminases >2 times the normal upper limit
Disorientation or alterations in consciousness without focal neurologic
signs in the absence of fever and hypotension
Negative results on the following tests, if obtained
Blood, throat, or cerebrospinal fluid cultures for another pathogen (blood
cultures may be positive for S. aureus).
Serologic tests for Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, leptospirosis, or measles

Name: ORZID2 GMENU DERM TSS STREP
DisplayText: Criteria for diagnosis of Streptococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome

Contents.Text: Working Group on Severe Streptococcal Infections JAMA 1993, 269:390
CRITERIA FOR DIAGNOSIS OF STREPTOCOCCAL TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME
These criteria were developed for epidemiologic purposes. Treat cases when
fewer criteria are met if streptococcal TSS seems likely.
1.) Isolation of Group A Streptococcus from a normally sterile site (eg. blood
cerebrospinal, pleural, or peritoneal fluid, tissue biopsy, or surgical wound)
2.) Hypotension (systolic blood pressure 90 mm Hg in adults)
3.) Two or more of the following:
(creatinine in adults, 2mg/dL, in children, two-times upper limit of normal
for age, in patients with pre-existing renal disease two-fold elevation over
(eg, two-times upper limit of normal for age of transaminases or bilirubin, in
patients with pre-existing liver disease two-fold elevation over baseline)
Soft tissue necrosis (eg, nectrotizing fasciitis, myositis, or gangrene)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa and various Enterobacteriaceae are uncommon endocarditis
pathogens. Risk factors include cirrhosis, IV drug use and prosthetic valve.
Choice of agents should be based on in vitro susceptibilities.
Consult Infectious Diseases and Cardiothoracic surgery in all cases.
Most cases of pseudomonas endocarditis occur in IV drug users.

Empirical treatment in a non-intravenous drug user
Wait for identification of pathogen before initiating antimicrobial therapy in
most cases. If empiric antimicrobial treatment is necessary, due to hemodynamic
instability or other severe disease, use:
Empirical treatment in an intravenous drug user
Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely pathogen, followed by streptococci and
enterococci. However, gram negative pathogens are often associated with
endocarditis in these patients. Culture results are key for appropriate therapy.
Consult Cardiology and Infectious Diseases for more information.
Mandell chapter: Endocarditis and intravascular infections

Retrospective studies show that patients with native valve staphylococcal
endocarditis treated with valve replacement and antimicrobials have a lower
mortality rate than those treated with antimicrobials alone. Consult
cardiothoracic surgery for all patients with staphylococcal endocarditis.

strains Infectious Disease consultation is recommended.

Ecthyma gangrenosum lesions commonly begin as painless red macules which
rapidly evolve into areas of induration that develop into pustules and-or
bullae. Ultimately, these become gangrenous ulcers. Ecthyma lesions
typically progress rapidly within 12 to 18 hours. They are often associated
with Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia, especially in neutropenic patients.
Recommend blood cultures and culture of skin exudates.
Consider combination therapy in patients with severe infections.

Contents.Text: GUIDELINES FOR ENDOCARDITIS PROPHYLAXIS AND PREVENTION OF
Antibiotic prophylaxis in dermatologic surgery remains an area of
uncertainty due to a paucity of data. Large, randomized, controlled trials
delineating the risk of surgical site infection, hematogenous total joint
infection, or infective endocardits following dermatologic surgery do not exist.
The common mechanistic pathway of both infective endocarditis and hematogenous
total joint infection is bacteremia. Bacteremia can occur as bacteria gain
intravascular access during a perforating dermatologic surgical procedure or may
occur secondarily as a result of extension of a surgical site infection into the

Erysipeloid is a localized cutaneous infection with Erysipelothrix rhusopathiae.
It is a zoonotic infection of fisherman, fish handlers, and butchers acquired by
direct animal contact, most commonly with fish, but also with other animals
(e.g., swine). It usually affects the hand or fingers and is characterized by
throbbing pain and a red rash with a purple center and an elevated border.
Localized infections can be treated with oral antimicrobials.
Severe, diffuse cutaneous infections or systemic infections with E.
rhusopathiae occur rarely after ingestion of undercooked pork or contaminated
seafood in immunosuppressed individuals.  These infections are treated
Treatment of systemic or severe diffuse cutaneous infection with E.
Treatment duration is at least 4 weeks. Infectious Disease Consult recommended.

Contents.Text: Esophagitis is usually associated with non-infectious diseases like
gastroesophageal reflux disease, mucositis and pill-induced esophagitis.
Esophageal infection occurs primarily in immunosuppressed individuals (e.g.
chemotherapy, transplantation, HIV) and rarely in healthy individuals. The
majority of infectious esophagitis is caused by Candida albicans,
cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus. Aphthous ulceration of the
esophagus is common in HIV infection.

Fever of unknown origin (FUO) is the occurrence of several episodes of fever
greater than 101 degrees Fahrenheit over a time period of at least 3 weeks
despite 1 week of hospital evaluation. Cases with FUO are often classified in
four categories: (1) classical, (2) neutropenic, (3) nosocomial, and (4) fever
in persons with HIV/AIDS. Empirical antimicrobial therapy is rarely indicated
Note that FUO in neutropenic patients refers to persistent fever that has
remained undiagnosed after extensive diagnostic work and empirical antimicrobial
therapy. New fever in patients with profound neutropenia is a different
syndrome and does require empirical antimicrobial therapy. Infectious Diseases
should be involved in any case where empirical treatment for fever of unknown
Mandell Chapter: Fever of Unknown Origin

for 4 to 6 weeks.  For moderate to severe disease, give intravenous therapy for
1 to 2 weeks followed by oral therapy.  For mild cases, start with oral therapy
or give intravenous therapy for only a few days followed by oral therapy for the
balance of 4 to 6 weeks.  Do not place a long-term intravascular access device
(e.g. a PICC line) until it is clear the patient will need long term intravenous
therapy. Consult Infectious Diseases or Orthopedic Surgery for more information.

Contents.Text: Foot ulcers WITH infection of surrounding tissues
FOOT ULCER IN PATIENT WITH DIABETES MELLITUS
Foot ulcers in patients with diabetes mellitus are colonized with bacteria.
Antimicrobials should not be used to treat colonization.
Cases with infection of surrounding tissues signified by erythema, warmth, local
tenderness, or purulent discharge should be treated with antimicrobials. Pain
may not be present in patients with neuropathy.  In patients with substantial
vascular disease, erythema and warmth may not be present and instead the tissues
will be dusky, mottled, or cool.  Capillary refill may be impaired.  Patients
with diabetes and ulcers are at risk for gangrenous infections.  If there is any
suggestion of gangrene, consult surgery immediately.

Diagnosis and treatment are complex, consult Infectious Diseases in all cases.
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly termed Pneumocystis carinii) is an ubiquitous
organism that causes disease in people with compromised cell-mediated immunity.
Disease is exceedingly rare in people with intact host defenses. Pneumonia is
the usual manifestation but P. jirovecii can infect extrapulmonary sites,
especially in patients who have been receiving prophylaxis with aerosolized
pentamidine. P. jirovecii disease occurs most commonly in people with AIDS and
The abbreviation PCP is often used for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It was derived
from the old species name, Pneumocystis carinii.
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) is the treatment of choice for P.
jirovecii disease, including disease that occurs despite TMP-SMZ prophylaxis.
Corticosteroids should be prescribed for patients with AIDS and P. jirovecii
pneumonia and an arterial oxygen tension <70 torr or an alveolar-arterial

Localized purulent infections include furuncles, carbuncles and cutaneous
abscesses. Nearly all are caused by Staphylococcus aureus. A furuncle is an
inflamed nodule that usually develops as a complication of folliculitis.  A
carbuncle is a more extensive lesion that extends further into the subcutaneous
tissue.  Contact a wound care nurse for more information.
Incision and drainage is the mainstay of therapy for carbuncles, cutaneous
The decision to administer antibiotics directed against S. aureus as an adjunct
to incision and drainage should be made based on the presence of systemic
inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) or in patients with markedly impaired
For recurrent skin abscesses in addition to culture and antibiotic therapy

Pseudomonas, Bordetella, and Brucella spp. usually grow aerobically (but can
show up in an anaerobic bottle). Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Porphyromonas, and
Prevotella spp. usually grow anaerobically (but can show up in an aerobic
bottle). Most other gram-negative bacilli are facultative, i.e. they can grow
in aerobic or anaerobic culture conditions.
Some antimicrobial combinations are synergistic in vitro against some Gram-
negative bacilli. Combination therapy has not been shown to improve outcomes
in most circumstances. Single drug therapy is used in most cases. Contact

peptostreptococci, so no additional anaerobic antimicrobials are needed
specifically to cover peptostreptococcus when drugs such as ampicillin-sulbactam
Optimal therapy depends on both the disease or syndrome and the pathogen. See

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU GRAM-POS FI TREAT ENTEROCOCCI

Contents.Text: The important human pathogens are Enterococcus faecium and Enterococcus
faecalis. The antimicrobial susceptibilities that are reported for enterococci
depend on the site of the sample. For all enterococci the microbiology
laboratory reports susceptibility for ampicillin and vancomycin. Additionally
the lab reports fluoroquinolone susceptibility for urinary isolates and
susceptibility to gentamicin synergy for bloodstream isolates. For more
information on culture and susceptibilities, contact the microbiology laboratory
Ampicillin is the drug of choice for enterococcal infections. Piperacillin is
also active against enterococcus. Cephalosporins are ineffective as single
agents for enterococcal infections. For patients who are allergic to penicillin
or infected with penicillin-resistant enterococcus, vancomycin is the preferred
drug. Nitrofurantoin is effective in urinary tract infections only. Linezolid
must be reserved for cases where no other drug can be used as it has many side
effects and drug interactions, is expensive, is bacteriostatic rather than
bactericidal, and its use promotes resistance.
Combination regimens include a primary anti-enterococcal agent (ampicillin or
vancomycin) plus gentamicin or streptomycin are synergistic in vitro and are
needed for severe infections like endocarditis or prosthetic joint infections.
See relevant disease/syndrome sections for more information. Milder diseases
like cystitis or wound infection can usually be treated with a single drug. For
more information on treatment of enterococcal infections, contact Infectious
Mandell chapter: Enterococcus Species, Streptococcus gallolyticus Group, and
Up-To-Date article: Treatment of enterococcal infection

Group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) is the most virulent
streptococcal species. Important syndromes include pharyngitis, cellulitis,
streptococcal toxic shock syndrome, necrotizing fasciitis, erysipelas, rheumatic
fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Optimal therapy depends on
both the disease or syndrome and the pathogen. See diagnosis/syndrome section

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU GRAM-POS FIN S. AUREUS

ORZID2 GMENU ABX STAPHYLOCOCCUS AUREUS DECOLONIZATION

Contents.Text: Staphylococcus aureus is a virulent pathogen, and staphylococcal disease tends
to relapse. Optimal therapy often involves intravenous therapy for defined
durations. See sections on specific syndromes (e.g., bacteremia or
Coagulase-negative staphylococci, including Staphylococcus epidermidis and
several less common species, are less virulent than S. aureus and are most
commonly pathogenic when they colonize plastic or metal devices in a patient
(e.g., intravenous catheters, prosthetic joints or heart valves). S.
lugdunensis is an uncommon but virulent coagulase-negative staphylococcus
species. S. saprophyticus is associated with urinary tract infections in women.
Beta-lactam antimicrobials are the most active drugs against beta-lactam
susceptible staphylococci. Penicillin is superior for penicillin-susceptible
staphylococci, but most strains are resistant. Nafcillin and oxacillin are
nearly as active as penicillin. Cefazolin or ceftriaxone (also beta-lactams are
next best. Vancomycin, a glycopeptide, is less active than the beta-lactams.
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, minocycline, and clindamycin are less effective
than beta-lactams for treatment of methicillin-susceptible staphylococcal
infections, but may be useful in patients with severe penicillin allergy. For
minocycline, and clindamycin are useful alternatives to to vancomycin, as they
are inexpensive and available in both intravenous and oral formulations. They
are preferred over linezolid in most circumstances because linezolid is
expensive, toxic with long-term use, and needed for treatment of highly
Combination regimens include a primary anti-staphylococcal agent (beta-lactam or
vancomycin) plus one or more supplemental drugs (e.g. gentamicin and/or
rifampin) often synergistic against staphylococci in vitro, but there is no
evidence that combination therapy improves outcomes in staphylococcal infections
in humans. Combination therapy has become the community standard for treatment
of prosthetic-valve staphylococcal endocarditis based on experimental models and
limited clinical data that combination therapy is superior (see endocarditis
Mandell chapter: Endocarditis and Intravascular Infections

Viridans streptococci are a heterogeneous group defined by their production of
green pigment on blood agar. Clinically important members of this group include
S. mutans, S. mitis, and S. sanguis. S. anginosus (formerly S. milleri) and
Streptococcus bovis are described separately. Viridans streptococci are
important, common pathogens in endocarditis and can also be contaminants in
cultures of blood and other specimens. Consult Infectious Diseases for more
Refer to Cardiovascular Section for diagnosis and treatment of endocarditis
Optimal therapy depends on both the disease or syndrome and the pathogen. See
Preferred treatment is penicillin or cefazolin. Vancomycin should be used only
in patients with beta-lactam allergy, or if beta-lactam resistance is strongly
suspected. For serious disease, consider addition of gentamicin for synergy.
Contact Infectious Diseases for more information.
Alternative for patient with penicillin allergy, or if beta-lactam resistance

Name: ORZID2 GMENU GRAM-POS INT RS COCCI PAIRS
DisplayText: Interim results:  Gram-positive cocci in pairs

Contents.Text: INTERIM RESULTS: GRAM-POSITIVE COCCI IN PAIRS
Aerobic Gram-positive cocci in pairs are usually streptococci, staphylococci, or
enterococci.These bacteria can be isolated under either aerobic or anaerobic
conditions.  Gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters are usually
staphylococci.  Gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains are usually streptococci
or enterococci.  Gram-positive cocci in "chains" are likely streptococci.  If
the lab reports Gram-positive cocci in "short chains", enterococci are likely.

Contents.DisplayText: Permethrin 1% lotion to the affected area for 10 minutes
Contents.Text: Permethrin 1% lotion Apply to affected area for 10 minutes then comb out
Lice are parasitic insects. Human lice survive by feeding on human blood.
To make a diagnosis, use a nit comb, bright light, or lens to find a louse
living on the scalp.  Dead nits may remain for months after successful
treatment.  Dead nits are usually located more than 6 mm from the scalp.
Lice are often transmitted by infected clothing and bedclothes but not by
ordinary furniture that is not typically in contact with hair or scalp.  Refer
to the following for advice on household cleaning for lice infestations:
Repeat if live lice are seen 7-10 days after treatment.

Contents.Text: HSV infection of the esophagus usually occurs in patients who are
immunocompromised, typically solid organ and bone marrow transplant
recipients. In healthy patients HSV esophagitis occurs occasionally,
usually in menu under the age of 40.
Patients usually present with odynophagia and dysphagia. Fever,
expigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and heartburn are less frequent.
Some patients may have coexistent herpes labialis or oropharyngeal
ulcers. Diagnosis is usually established with an upper endoscopy.
Suggestive findings may also be seen during a barium swallow.
Spontaneous resolution usually occurs in immunocompetent patients after
one to two weeks. Patients may respond more quickly if treated with a
Treatment for mild to moderate disease

Antibody deficiency typically leads to recurrent, severe respiratory tract
infections associated with encapsulated bacteria, especially Streptococcus
pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, and to a lesser extent, Staphylococcus
aureus. Recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia are common syndromes.
Gastrointestinal disease associated with Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or
rotavirus is also common in some patients.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU IMMUNOCOM ALTERED MICRO FLORA

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Ip)
A rich, diverse microbial flora lives on or in skin, mucosal surfaces, and
respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts of healthy people.  This flora prevents
disease by inhibiting the growth of potential pathogens.  Disruption of the
normal flora, usually by antimicrobial therapy, reduces this barrier and
increases the risk of infectious disease.  Patients exposed to broad-spectrum
antimicrobials are at greater risk for colonization with resistant bacteria,
fungal infections, and Clostridium difficile colitis.  During hospitalization,
many patients become colonized with more resistant organisms like methicillin-
resistant Staphylococcus aureus and resistant Gram-negative bacilli.
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Ip)
Humans are protected by a broad array of host defenses that fall into two major
categories: innate and immune host defenses.  Innate defense operate
continuously without specific antigenic stimulation and immune defenses are
primed by and respond to antigenic stimulation.
Each type of host defense protects against a specific set of organisms.  As a
result, infectious diseases more common because of host defense defects in an
individual patient are usually predictable from that patient's host defense
defects.  For example, antibody or complement deficiencies predispose patients
to disease with encapsulated organisms but not fungi.  Defects in cell-mediated
immunity predispose patients to infections with mycobacteria or cytomegalovirus
but not Escherichia coli or influenza virus.  Suspected cases of infectious
disease must be evaluated in the context of the patient's host defects.
Management, including possible antimicrobial therapy, should be initiated on the
basis of the most likely offending pathogens.

usually a consequence of other diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus.
Complement deficiency leads to increased rates of infections, usually of the
upper respiratory tract, but also occasionally with bacteremia or meningitis.
Pathogens are usually Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and

Contents.Text: Prevention of fungal infections in a patient with malignancy
Prevention of antiviral infection in a patient with malignancy
Malignancies affect host defenses in many ways.  Hematogenous malignancies can
diminish the effectiveness of neutrophils and other cells involved in host
defense.  Tumors often disrupt mucous membranes or blood vessels and allow
contaminating organisms into hollow cavities or the bloodstream.  Chemotherapy
used to treat these malignancies often impairs mucus membranes and suppresses
Ordinarily, empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for patients with
malignancy and fever unless they have neutropenia or a specific infectious
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Ip)
Adequate nutrition is necessary for optimal host defense function.  A few days
of malnutrition can decrease host defenses, mainly cell-mediated immunity. The
degree of compromised immunity increases with the duration of malnutrition.
However, nutritional replacement has not been shown to improve outcomes in
patients with mild-moderate malnutrition.  Enteral nutritional replacement is
far superior to and safer than intravenous hyperalimentation.
Empirical antimicrobials are not indicated for malnourished patients with fever
but without evidence of a specific infectious disease.
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Ip)
Several types of neurological dysfunction predispose patients to infectious
diseases.  Comatose patients are unable to keep weight off dependent tissues,
predisposing them to decubitus ulcers and pressure necrosis.  Atelectasis is
common in obtunded patients who cannot cough or breathe deeply.  When patients
require artificial ventilation, intubation compounds the risk of respiratory
Neurological dysfunction of the bladder can interfere with normal bladder
emptying and predisposes patients to bacteriuria.  The risk of bacteruria
increases if patients are catheterized.  Antimicrobial treatment is not
indicated for asymptomatic bacteriuria.  It provides no benefit and increases
risk of colonization with resistant organisms.
Neurological dysfunction predisposes patients to aspiration of oropharyngeal or
gastric contents.  Aspiration causes fever, inflammation, and/or pulmonary
infiltrate, but does not require antimicrobial treatment. Bacterial pneumonia
occurs in a minority of patients who experience significant aspiration,
typically about 3 days later.  Typically, the patient improves for the first 2
days and then worsens as bacterial pneumonia develops with increased fever, new
or progressive infiltrates, leukocytosis, and newly purulent sputum.
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU NEUT FEVER MOD THERAPY

Contents.Text: The risk of severe, rapidly progressive infections increases when the absolute
neutrophil count (ANC, segmented neutrophils plus bands) is less than 500
cells/microliter.  The risk increases dramatically when the ANC is <100
cells/microliter.  Because of these risks, patients with fever and neutropenia
to this degree should receive empirical antimicrobial therapy immediately.
Empirical therapy should also be given to patients with fever and ANC 500-1000
cells/microliter when the concentration is expected to be <500 cells/microliter
within the next 48 hours.  For this purpose, fever is defined as a single
Since infection can be rapidly progressive and severe, broad-spectrum
antimicrobials are given urgently to patients with neutropenic fever as defined
above.  Vancomycin should only be given when there are clear indications for its
Candidates for empirical treatment with oral antimicrobials include those who
are febrile but who have no evidence of focal infection or signs or symptoms of
severe disease, like hypotension.  Outpatient antimicrobials for neutropenic
fever must be ordered only in consultation with Hematology-Oncology or
Rolston KVI Clin Infect Dis 2004, 39: S44

duration of neutropenia, and the presence of other host defense defects or

Contents.Text: Patients with absent or dysfunctional spleens are at risk of sepsis, most
commonly with Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus
influenzae.  Less common pathogens include Babesia microtii (from Ixodes tick
bites), Capnocytophaga phagocytosis, and Capnocytophaga canimorsus (from dog
The risk of severe infection is related to the reason for splenectomy and the
time since splenectomy.  Risk is greatest during the first year after
splenectomy and then decreases with time but never reaches the risk level of
immunocompetent patients.  Patients who have had a splenectomy as a result of
Hodgkin disease or thalassemia are at greatest risk of infection.  The risk is
intermediate in patients who have had splenectomy for spherocytosis, idiopathic
thrombocytopenic purpura, or portal hypertension, and lowest in patients who
When asplenic patients present with fever or other symptoms suggesting systemic
bacterial infection, obtain blood cultures and treat immediately with
antimicrobials active against the likely pathogens.  For early empirical
treatment, some patients are given a supply of antimicrobials and instructed to
take them when they first become ill and then to seek medical attention
immediately thereafter.  Some patients at high risk of infection are treated
with antimicrobials continuously to prevent infections.  Contact Infectious

susceptibility to respiratory infectious diseases and several systemic
infectious diseases with bacterial and viral pathogens.  Compounds found in
tobacco or tobacco smoke interfere with several host defense mechanisms in the

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX E COLI INFECT
Contents.Text: Escherichia coli [CLICK HERE], including varieties listed below:
Most episodes of acute diarrhea are self limited and do not need to be evaluated
or treated. In most mild to moderate cases, antimicrobial therapy does not
provide benefit and may prolong symptoms or shedding. Antimicrobial therapy is
detrimental in cases involving enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli.
The decision for whether to test stool depends on illness severity and duration,
the likelihood of specific infectious agents and the severity of any underlying
diseases. Send stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing if the patient has
volume depletion warranting hospitalization, bloody stool, >/= 6 stools in 24
hours, temperature >38.4 C, or severe abdominal pain or signs of sepsis, or is
>/= 70 years old or substantially immunocompromised. Replace fluid losses and
correct electrolyte imbalances. Patients with diarrhea who were potentially
exposed during a community outbreak of infectious diarrhea should be tested for
the suspected bacterial, viral, and parasitic agents regardless of symptom
Obtain blood cultures if patients have signs of septicemia, suspected enteric
fever (e.g., fever plus recent travel to an endemic area or contact with someone
who has enteric fever), other systemic symptoms, immune compromise, or other
Bloody diarrhea can represent hemorrhagic colitis or dysentery. Antimicrobial
therapy and antimotility agents are not recommended in most patients with bloody
diarrhea due to an increased risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome when using these
agents. Obtain a stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing and reserve
antimicrobial and antimotility agent treatment until results are known. Enteric
pathogen PCR testing results are reported within 2 hours between 7am and 11pm.
For more information on when an antimicrobial is indicated or if the patient has

INTERIM REPORT OF GRAM-POSITIVE COCCI IN PAIRS AND CHAINS
If chains are reported, streptococci are likely. If short chains are
reported, enterococci are likely. Beta-lactam antimicrobials are more effective
than vancomycin in killing susceptible streptococci and enterococci, so
penicillin or ampicillin should be used if resistance is unlikely.
If the patient is severely ill or is likely to be colonized with resistant
organisms, treat with vancomycin until susceptibility results are known.

variable, and (3)small and pleomorphic.  The large, uniformly rod-shaped Gram-
positive bacilli are usually Bacillus spp. (aerobic) or Clostridium species
(anaerobic).  Bacillus spp. include Bacillus subtilis (usually a contaminant),
Bacillus cereus, and Bacillus anthracis.  Medium-sized Gram-positive bacilli are

usually contaminants. Uncommonly such organisms prove to be Listeria
monocytogenes, which when present in a blood culture is likely a pathogen.
Listeria is more likely in patients with impaired cell-mediated immunity,
pregnant women, elderly and patients on immunosuppressive therapy for
Empirical treatment if there is a strong suspicion of listeria

Contents.Text: When catheter-related bacteremia is suspected, draw blood cultures from both the
catheter and a peripheral vein. If patient is seriously ill (hypotension,
hypoperfusion, signs and symptoms of organ failure) remove catheter and culture
tip. In patients who are moderately ill (e.g. hypotension, organ failure),
remove catheter and culture tip if patient has a prosthetic valve, pacemaker or
vascular graft. Start empirical antibiotics while awaiting culture results.
Narrow therapeutic spectrum based on sensitivities of cultured pathogens.

Mandell's Principles and Practice of Infectious Disease Online Access
This section gives brief advice on antimicrobial treatment for specific
pathogens. Colonization by pathogens in most non-sterile sites rarely requires
antimicrobial therapy. If there is a question about whether an isolate should
If culture and susceptibility results are available, use them to select
antimicrobial therapy. If culture and susceptibility results are not available,
use clinical judgment to decide the appropriate spectrum of coverage. If you
need advice on a disease or syndrome, return to the main menu and proceed to
that disease or syndrome. In most cases, culture and susceptibility results
should be used when they become available to select antimicrobials. This
section gives the most common drugs to treat most microorganisms. Contact
Infectious Diseases or consult a textbook such as Mandell's Principles and
Practice of Infectious Disease for more information.
Microbiology results often become available in stages. Interim reports
typically indicate the morphology and staining properties of an organism before
final identification and susceptibility reports are available. Use an interim
report along with the patient's presenting syndrome to refine the empirical
therapy regimen pending final results. Use this section to adjust antimicrobial
therapy based on an interim report.

Moxifloxacin 0.5% ophthalmic drops: 1-2 drops in affected eye(s) q1h ($) [M]
Keratitis is an emergency requiring prompt treatment to prevent vision loss.
Keratitis is associated with viral or bacterial infection, trauma, foreign
bodies, or allergies. About half of cases of infectious keratitis are caused by
bacterial pathogens, most commonly Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp., and
gram-negative bacilli. Viruses are the second leading cause. Fungi and parasites
have also been associated with corneal infection. Obtain corneal scrapings for
gram stain and bacterial and viral cultures and start empirical therapy
If bacterial keratitis is likely, contact ophthalmology to obtain a corneal
scraping and give empirical antibacterial drops immediately. Modify therapy
based on Ophthalmology and/or Infectious Diseases recommendations. Ophthalmic
corticosteroids are contraindicated in patients with keratitis.
Treatment should be continued until ulcer and other signs of infectious
keratitis have resolved. A minimum of two weeks and in rare cases, up to a month
Mild to moderate bacterial keratitis empirical treatment
Patient may require vancomycin 50mg/mL eye drops q1h in addition to gentamicin
eye drops. Vancomycin eye drops must be specially compounded and managed by
Up-to-Date article:  Complications of contact lenses

The majority of leukocytosis cases are due to infection but a sizable minority
are associated with physiological stress, inflammation, medications (e.g
glucosteroids), and hematological conditions. In a review of 100 cases of
extreme leukocytosis (more than 25000 leukocytes per microliter with more than
50% granulocytes) at the Minneapolis VA, only 48 were from infectious problems.
Infection should be considered as a possible stimulus for leukocytosis in a
patient with leukocytosis. Antimicrobials should be administered if the patient
has a syndrome or disease that calls for antimicrobials. Antimicrobials should
not be administered solely to treat a patient with leukocytosis and no other
Wanahita et al., Clinical Infectious Diseases (2002), 34.1585-92
Reding et al., The American Journal of Medicine (1998), 104.12-16

Contents.Text: Patients who have been bitten while in endemic areas of New England, Mid-
Atlantic States, Minnesota and Wisconsin where local rate of Ixodes scapularis
tick infection rate with Borrelia burgdorferi is equal to or greater than 20%
may be treated with prophylactic antibiotics for prevention of Lyme disease.
Using a wait and see method by monitoring for signs and symptoms of Lyme disease
is also an acceptable approach in patients who have been bitten by an Ixodes
All following criteria must be met to be considered for prophylactic treatment:
1. Doxyclycline is not contraindicated (i.e. allergy, pregnant, lactating)
2. Attached tick is reliably identified as an adult or nymphal Ixodes
scalpularis. Follow link below for identification guide:
3. Tick is attached for greater than or equal to 36 hours based on degree of
tick engorgement with blood or likely time of exposure to tick infested area.
4. Prophylaxis must be started within 72 hours after time tick was removed.
5. Patient was exposed to tick bite in endemic areas where rate of Ixodes
scapularis infection with Borrelia burgdorferi is greater than 20%. Minnesota
counties where there is high risk of tickborne disease are shown in the
Providers can call the Minnesota Department of Health (651-201-5414) or the
Wisconsin Department of Health Services (608-266-1865) for specific rates of B.
burdorferi infection of ixodes ticks in area where a patient was exposed.
Contact Infectious Disease if patient was exposed to an Ixodes scapularis tick
bite in New England or Mid-Atlantic States.
Prophylactic treatment if all above criteria are met

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Ip)
ERYTHEMA MIGRANS ASSOCIATED WITH LYME DISEASE
Erythema migrans is the first manifestation of Lyme disease in 70-80% of cases.
It is typically an erythematous circular rash, 5cm or larger in diameter, with
induration and central clearing (although other patterns occur). It usually
develops at the site of the bite and/or in one or more distant locations. The
rash occurs 3 to 30 days after the bite. Rashes with onset less than 3 days
after a tick bite are not from Lyme disease.
For pregnant patients or patients with doxycycline allergy

Acute mastoiditis most commonly occurs as a suppurative complication of acute
otitis media with symptoms lasting less than one month. Diagnosis is supported
by CT or MRI imaging and culture of drainage. Intravenous antibiotics followed
by oral antibiotics and drainage of middle ear are sufficient treatment in most
cases. Mastoidectomy is necessary if abscess has formed in the mastoid bone.
Antimicrobial treatment of uncomplicated acute mastoiditis should cover
pathogens most commonly associated with acute otitis media, including
Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. Patients with acute
exacerbation of chronic mastoiditis and those with complicated disease (e.g.
suppurative complications of mastoiditis) and those with multiple episodes of
acute otitis media should receive treatment for coverage of additional pathogens
including Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and gram-negative
Treatment with intravenous antimicrobials for 7 days followed by oral
antimicrobials for a total duration of 3 weeks.
Step down treatment after initial intravenous antibiotic treatment in patients
who can tolerate oral therapy. Base selection on culture results. Adjust for a
total duration of 3 weeks of antimicrobial therapy.
Chronic mastoiditis most commonly occurs as a suppurative complication of
chronic otitis media with symptoms lasting months to years. Diagnosis is
supported by CT or MRI imaging and culture of drainage. Long term treatment with
topical antimicrobials is first line therapy. Infection is often polymicrobial
including Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and anaerobes. Treatment
should be managed in collaboration with otolaryngology and includes topical
antimicrobials, care of external auditory canal, and is some cases
mastoidectomy. If possible, withhold therapy until a pathogen is identified by
culture of drainage to direct therapy.
Mandell chapter: Otitis Externa, Otitis Media, and Mastoiditis

Community-acquired bacterial sinusitis is most often due to Streptococcus
pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae or Moraxella catarrhalis. Streptococci,
Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes are isolated less frequently.
Treatment for first 10 days of illness
Treat with decongestants, analgesics, and nasal saline spray.
Treatment of cases that have not improved in 10 days despite
treatment with decongestants, analgesics, and nasal saline.
If symptoms worsen despite 72 hours or  fail to improve after 3-5 days of
initial empirical antimicrobial therapy, broaden coverage, switch to different
antimicrobial class and treat 7-10 days. If symptoms continue to worsen or there
is no improvement after 3-5 more days of treatment, obtain CT to investigate
non-infectious or suppurative causes. ENT consultation is recommended. If
sinuses are aspirated, specimens should be cultured.

Prevent tinea pedis infection by keeping feet clean and dry.  In patients with

Contents.Text: "Mandell" chapter: Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases
Suppurative Parotitis. Acute bacterial parotitis affects primarily elderly,
malnourished, dehydrated or post-operative patients. Symptoms include fever,
toxicity, and tender swelling along the mandible with prurulent drainage from
the parotid duct. Suppurative parotitis is usually unilateral whereas viral
parotitis is usually bilateral. Pain is intense and aggressive, analgesic
therapy is required. Progression of infection may lead to massive swelling
of the neck, respiratory obstruction, septicemia and osteomyelitis of
adjacent facial bones. Empiric antibiotics are required for Staphylococcus
aureus if bacterial and surgical drainage usually necessary.
Chronic Parotitis. Parotitis is recurrent with intermittent acut
exacerbations. Chronic, low-grade bacterial infection results in functional
destruction of the salivary gland. It may be confused with Sjogren's
syndrome, a noninfectious illness. Therapy includes systemic antibiotics.
Parotidectomy may eventually be required for patients with long-standing
Viral Parotitis. Mumps parotitis is characterized by the rapid, painful
swelling of one or both parotid glands witin 2 to 3 weeks after exposure to
the mumps virus. Mumps usually involves both parotid glands whereas
bacterial parotitis is unilateral. Other viral causes of parotitis include
influenza and enteroviruses. Mumps parotitis usually resolves spontaneously
in 5 to 10 days. Provide symptomatic relief of pain and fever and maintain
hydration to prevent secondary bacterial infection.

MORE ABOUT PHARYNGITIS/ TONSILLITIS AND THE MODIFIED CENTOR SCORE
As most cases are of viral origin, antimicrobials are not indicated in these
cases. Warm saltwater gargle rinses and throat lozenges provide temporary relief
of throat pain. Five to 10% of cases are caused by group A Streptococcus.
Antimicrobial treatment reduces symptoms by one day, prevents suppurative
complications and prevents acute rheumatic fever, an uncommon disease in US
Streptococcal pharyngitis or tonsillitis should be suspected when patients have
fever and exudate on the pharyngeal wall or tonsils without symptoms like cough,
nasal congestion, or runny nose that suggest viral infection or common cold. If
streptococcal pharyngitis is suspected in adults, perform PCR testing for group
A streptococci and treat only if positive.
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a rare cause of pharyngitis. N. gonorrhoeae should be
considered for patients with risk factors for sexually transmitted diseases. N.
gonorrhoeae infections must be reported to the state health department and this
will be done by Infection Control if the culture is positive.
Used to estimate the likelihood that a patient with sore throat has
streptococcal pharyngitis and whether rapid PCR testing should be performed.
2) Swollen and tender anterior cervical nodes = 1 point
3) Temperature greater than 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Centigrade) = 1
Patients with a score of 0 or 1 are at very low risk. PCR testing and antibiotic
treatment are not indicated. Patients with a score of 2 to 4 are at moderate to
high risk. PCR testing should be obtained in these patients to determine if GAS
is present. In patients with a score of 4 or greater, consider empiric

ORZID2 GMENU NECROT INFECT DIRECT THERAPY

Contents.Text: Call Surgery immediately and consult Infectious Diseases in all cases.
Necrotizing infections involve tissues skin and/or deeper structures, including
fascia and muscle.  These infections destroy tissue, often rapidly, and are
often fatal if not treated promptly and appropriately.  Necrotizing infections
usually result from trauma, surgery, and/or ischemia.  These infections can be
monomicrobial (e.g., with streptococci or clostridia) or polymicrobial (usually
with a mixture of aerobes and anaerobes).  Fournier gangrene is usually
associated with mixed infection.  Myonecrosis is most commonly associated with
Necrotizing infections differ from cellulitis in several ways.  Necrotic
infections typically have one or more of the following: (1) severe, constant
pain, (2) bullae, (3) bruising or necrosis of overlying skin, (4) gas in tissues
which can be felt or seen on images, (5) edema that extends beyond areas of
erythema, (6) local anesthesia, and (7) signs of systemic toxicity, such as
fever, leukocytosis, delirium, or renal failure.
Necrotizing infections must be treated with both antimicrobial therapy and
surgical procedures (excision and/or drainage).  Call surgery to see the patient
immediately in all cases.  Obtain tissue and blood cultures and begin empirical
antimicrobials.  For several necrotic diseases and/or pathogens, a combination
of two antimicrobials is recommended including a bactericidal antimicrobial
active at the cell wall or membrane (e.g., beta-lactam or glycopeptide) and an
antimicrobial that rapidly inhibits protein synthesis and thus inhibits toxin
Repeat debridement should be performed daily until no further debridement is
necessary. Antibiotic therapy should be tailored as soon as culture results
Administer antibiotics until further debridement is no longer necessary, the
patient has improved clinically, and fever has been absent for 48-72 hours.
Mandell chapter: Cellulitis and subcutaneous tissue infections
Montravers P Curr Opin Infect Dis 2016, 29:131

MASCC RISK INDEX FOR FEBRILE NEUTROPENIA
SCORING TOOL TO IDENTIFY LOW RISK FEBRILE NEUTROPENIC PATIENTS
Patients with minimal risk of severe or rapidly progressive infection can be
treated with oral antimicrobials safely.  Many can be treated as outpatients.
Use the scoring index to identify febrile neutropenic patients who at
sufficiently low risk for severe infections and can be treated with outpatient
Severity of symptoms of illness (choose one only)
Solid tumor or no previous fungal infection4
Outpatient status at onset of fever3
The highest possible score is 26. A risk index score of 21 or greater indicates
that the patient is likely to be at LOW RISK for complications and morbidity.
This is a guide.  Always use clinical judgement.

Contents.DisplayText: Infections in bone or joint prostheses
Contents.Text: Infections in bone or joint prostheses
In acute osteomyelitis, symptoms have been present for several days to weeks.
Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by a longer duration of symptoms,
sometimes months or years, and often dead, necrotic bone is present.  There is
considerable overlap between the syndromes of acute and chronic osteomyelitis.
Symptom duration may be unreliable in a patient with neuropathy.
Obtain material for gram stain and culture before initiating antimicrobials.
Blood and bone cultures are ideal.  Sinus tracts are often colonized with
multiple species and usually only one or two are pathogens in bone.  If
Staphylococcus aureus is present, it is likely to be a pathogen in bone.
Empirical antimicrobial therapy is the same for acute and chronic osteomyelitis,
but necrotic bone must often be removed for cure of chronic osteomyelitis.  If
complete debridement is not possible, long-term suppressive antimicrobials may
be needed.  Consult Infectious Diseases for more information.
The most important pathogens are S. aureus and streptococci.  Gram negative
bacilli are common pathogens in osteomyelitis associated with diabetic foot
Duration of treatment and route will vary with differences in location of
infection, infecting organism, and host comorbidities.  In general treat
for 4 to 6 weeks.  For difficult location (e.g. spine) or difficult bacteria
(e.g. staphylococcus, pseudomonas) give intravenous therapy for 4 to 6 weeks.
For moderate cases, give intravenous therapy for 1 to 2 weeks followed
by oral therapy for the balance of 4 to 6 weeks.  For mild cases, start with
intravenous therapy for only a few days followed by oral therapy for the
Recommend Orthopedic, Neurosurgery (for spine or skull osteomyelitis), Podiatry
(for foot infections), and Infectious Diseases consults.
Treat for 4 to 6 weeks.  Do not place a long-term intravascular access device
(e.g. a PICC line) until it is clear the patient will need long-term intravenous
therapy.  Consult Infectious Diseases or Orthopedic Surgery for more

Contents.Text: Antimicrobials are not indicated for uncomplicated pancreatitis.
In cases of necrotizing pancreatitis without infection, antimicrobial
prophylaxis does not improve patient outcomes.  Antimicrobials increase the risk
of fungal superinfection and should not be used.
Antimicrobials are indicated for cases with pancreatic abscess, infected
pancreatic pseudocyst, or infected necrotic pancreas (phlegmon).  The diagnosis
of infection can be difficult and may require aspiration.  Consultation with
Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases is encouraged.
In cases with necrosis, aspirate necrotic material (fine needle under CT or
ultrasound guidance) for smear and culture.  Uninfected cases should not receive
antimicrobials. Consider transfer to a higher level of care.
>>  Pancreatic ABSCESS, infected pancreatic pseudocyst, or infected necrotic
pancreas (phlegmon).  Duration of therapy is typically 2 to 4 weeks.

Periodontal disease, including gingivitis and periodontitis, may progress into
more severe disease or cause hematogenous spreading of bacteria if left
untreated. All patients with periodontal disease should be referred to the
dental service for assessment and direction of treatment. In the presence of
gingivitis, the most commonly isolated subgingival flora includes Prevotella
intermedia, Capnocytophaga spp, Finegoldia magna and Peptostreptococcus. In the
presence of periodontitis, flora increases in complexity to most commonly
include Porphyromonas gingivalis, P. intermedia, Aggregatibacter
actinomycetemcomitans, Tanneralla forsythensis and Treponema denticola.

advancing disease, severe pain, patients with immunocompromising conditions)

Diagnosis and treatment are complex, consult Infectious Diseases in all cases.
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly termed Pneumocystis carinii) in an ubiquitious
organism that causes disease in people with compromised cell-mediated immunity.
Disease is exceedingly rare in people with intact host defenses. Pneumonia is
the usual manifestation but P. jirovecii can infect extrapulmonary sites,
especially in patients who have been receiving prophylaxis with aerosolized
pentanmidine. P. jirovecii disease occurs most commonly in people with AIDS and
The abbreviation PCP is often used for Pneumocystis pneumonia. It was derived
from the old species name, Pneumocystis carinii.
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) is the treatment of choice for P.
jirovecii disease, including disease that occurs despite TMP-SMZ prophylaxis.
Corticosteriods should be prescribed for patients with AIDS and P. jirovecii
pneumonia and an arterial oxygen tension <70 torr or an alveolar-arterial oxygen
Preferred treatment for mild to moderate disease or step-down treatment once

Postseptal cellulitis (orbital cellulitis) is often preceded by sinusitis and
requires immediate consultation with otolaryngology and ophthalmology. Urgent
surgical drainage may be necessary. The most common pathogenic organisms in
adults are streptococci, Haemophilus influenzae, anaerobes, and Staphylococcus
Contact otolaryngology or ophthalmology immediately for urgent surgical
drainage. Broad-spectrum empirical antimicrobials should be used until a
pathogen can be identified from the drainage fluid.
Orbital cellulitis should be treated until all signs of infection have resolved.
Uncomplicated orbital cellulitis should be treated for minimum of 2 weeks and
complicated orbital cellulitis (severe ethmoid sinusitis and bony destruction of
sinus) should be treated for at least 4 weeks.
Concern for central nervous system involvement or alternative to above:

results.  Adjust duration based on criteria above.

Preseptal cellulitis involves soft tissues in front of the orbital septum and
the eyelids and is often preceded by sinusitis. Infection does not involve the
orbital contents. The most common pathogenic organisms in adults are
streptococci, Haemophilus influenzae, anaerobes, and Staphylococcus aureus.
Treat  under the guidance of ophthalmology and/or otolaryngology. Intravenous
antimicrobials are indicated initially for treatment of moderate to severe
disease. Switch to oral antimicrobials when the patient's symptoms improve and
the patient can tolerate oral medications.
Treatment of mild to moderate disease
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 1 DS PO BID ($) [R,DI] for 5 days
<AND> vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV q12h ($) [R] for 5 days
Carlisle et al., American Family Physician. 2015, 92(2)106-112

Name: ORZID2 GMENU PREV EXACERBATIONS COPD
DisplayText: Azithromycin for Prevention of Exacerbations of COPD

Contents.Text: Azithromycin for Prevention of Exacerbations in Advanced COPD
Daily azithromycin prevents chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
exacerbations in people with advanced COPD (Albert et al, see below).
Of note, in the study there was no benefit in the most severly ill
subgroup that was on the most pulmonary medications. People
with frequent exacerbations have more doctor visits and hospitalizations than
people with fever or no exacerbations. Frequent exacerbations are associated
with rapid decline in lung function and quality of life and increased risk of
To receive daily azithromycin from St Cloud VAHCS, patients must meet the
following criteria and receive approval from Pulmonology. The evidence
that benefits of daily azithromycin outweigh risks is limited to people who
*Clinical diagnosis of COPD (>= 10 pack-years cigarette smoking, a ratio of
post bronchodialator forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) to
forced vital capacity of <70%, and a postbronchodialator FEV1 of <80%
*Were either using continuous supplemental oxygen or had received systemic
glucocoricoids within the previous year, < OR >
*Had gone to an emergency room or had been hospitalized for an acute
*Use of medications that are associated with torsades de pointes (with the
*Use of medications that prolong the QTc interval
If, after trying all of the standard treatments, patients are still having
acute exacerbations of COPD, long-term antibiotic treatment with Azitromycin
If the patient meets the criteria and is willing to have audiometiric testing
and an electrocardiogram, please place a Pulmonology Consult for long-term
Azithromycin therapy for the prevention of exacerbations of COPD.

Contents.Text: Antimicrobials prevent P. jirovecii disease in persons with AIDS and
less than 200 CD4 T lymphocytes/microliter or those who have had
Prophylaxis should be considered for patients with severe protein
malnutrition, primary immunodeficiency diseases, organ transplantation,
persistent CD4 T lymphocytes <200/microliter, or cytotoxic or
immunosuppressive therapy. Persons with short courses of
corticosteroids are not at sufficiently high risk, but prophylaxis
should be considered for those who are receiving corticosteroids at
doses equivalent to at least 16mg daily for more than 8 weeks. Dose
and duration of prophylaxis varies with the indication. Please contact
Infectious Diseases or Hematology/Oncology for more information.
Prophylaxis should be discontinued when host defenses are restored.
Prophylaxis should be discontinued in persons with AIDS on highly
active antiretroviral therapy when the CD4 cell concentrations remain
over 200 cells/microliter for 3 months in patients, except that

PREVENTION OF VIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Chemotherapy with purine analogues such as fludarabine, cladribine or
pentostatin results in major cellular-immunodeficiency that may outlast the
exposure by months and enhances the risk for viral infections.
Recommend antiviral prophylaxis for patients treated with purine analogues,
if at least one of the following risk factors is present:
e) Prolonged Mild or Moderate Neutropenia: Mild <1000 Neutrophils/
microLiters (Grade III neutropenia) OR Moderate: <500 Neutrophils/
Duration: Antiviral prophylaxis should be initiated in the first week of
therapy and continued until 2 months after completion of therapy.
Alemtuzumab is a potent reactivator of latent intracellular pathogens,
including CMV. Chemotherapy with alemtuzumab results in major cellular-
immunodeficiency that may outlast the exposure by months and enhances the
risk for viral infections. The risk of viral disease increases with the
intensity and duration of functional T-cell suppression experienced with
Duration: Initiate antiviral prophylaxis with alemtuzumab therapy and
continue therapy for at least 2 months after last dose or until CD4 counts
are greater than or equal to 200 cells/ul, whichever is later.

Contents.Text: Mandel Chapter: Prophylaxis and Empirical Therapy of Infection in
Sandherr,M et al, Annals of Oncology 17: 1051-1059, 2006
Solid tumors do not significantly compromise the cellular immune system.
Therefore, patients are at low risk for opportunistic viral infections.
Documented invasive viral infections are very rare. Coincidental
mucocutaneous infections by herpes simplex are easily treated and do no
result in life-threatening invasive infections. Reactivation of
Cytomegavirus (CMV) or Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is rarely observed.
In patients with acute leukemia, treatment is highly aggressive and consists
of a combination of various cytotoxic agents administered in sequential
cycles as induction, consolidation and maintenance therapy. Persistent, i.e.
>10 days and profound neutropenia (<500 neutrophils) regularly occurs and
correlates with the risk of developing fever and infections. Almost all viral
infections during neutropenia constitute reactivations of herpes viruses.
None of the available studies demonstrated an effect of antiviral prophylaxis
on the initiation of antibiotic treatment, number of febrile days, duration
of antibiotic treatment, and onset of opportunistic infections. Therefore, no
recommendation for antiviral prophylaxis in patients with acute leukemia can
Rituximab is a monoclonal anti-CD-20 antibody used for treatment of
lymphomas. It leads to a profound depletion of circulating B-cells. B-cells
recover usually within 3-6 months after treatment. Prolonged administration
of rituximab (e.g., maintenance treatment >12 months) may result in a
significant decrease in levels of immunoglobulin M. Parvovirus B19 and JC-
papovavirus infections have been reported with maintenance rituximab therapy,
but drugs that would prevent these infections are not available. There is no
substantial increase in risk of reactivation of herpes viruses (including
Recommend routine testing for Hepatitis B virus prior to initiating Rituximab

Prophylaxis for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) or Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
Prophylaxis for Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses
Patients with active malignant disease are at higher risk for upper
respiratory infections due to influenza, parainfluenza or respiratory
syncytial virus (RSV). Although response to vaccination with the attenuated
influenza vaccine in patients on chemotherapy is variable, ranging
from 24-75%, immunoprophylaxis with the influenza vaccine is recommended for
patients with active malignant disease or chemotherapy, lymphoproliferative
disease, or multiple myeloma. In areas and seasons where influenza is
endemic, chemoprophylaxis can be considered in addition to vaccination in
exposed patients with a high risk of influenza complications.
Select for recommendations for antiviral prophylaxis
Prophylaxis and monitoring for CMV reactivation is not recommended unless the
patient has received an allogeneic HSCT. Usually the recommendations for
surveillance and prophylaxis of CMV infections from the institution
performing the HSCT will be followed.
Reactivation of chronic hepatitis B in patients undergoing immunosuppressive
or antineoplastic treatment is a severe complication. Patients with positive
HBsAg, chronic hepatitis B infection, or a previous episode of HBV
reactivation who will receive immunosuppressive therapy should receive
Recommend routine testing for Hepatits B prior to initiating Rituximab

PREVENTION OF FUNGAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Antifungal chemoprophylaxis is often given to patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for acute leukemia expected to have profound neutropenia (less than
100 neutrophils and bands per milliliter) for more than 10 days and for patients
receiving allogeneic stem cell transplantation.  For most other patients the
expected benefits do not outweigh the risks of adverse effects and selection of
Antifungal is usually given until the absolute neutrophil concentration
increases to more than 500 cells/microliter in patients undergoing induction
chemotherapy for leukemia.  Duration is 100 days for patients undergoing stem
cell transplantation.  Some physicians continue prevention after 100 days if
corticosteroids are part of the immunosuppressive regimen.
Recommend posaconazole prophylaxis for patients with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.
Contact Hematology Oncology or Infectious Disease for more information.
Patients who have had invasive fungal infection in the recent past and who are
about to become neutropenic may require chemoprophylaxis.  Contact Hematology-
Oncology or Infectious Disease for more information.
Duration of therapy: during period of expected neutropenia
For patients being treated for AML:
Posaconazole 300mg Tablets twice daily on day 1, then 300mg once daily on
day 2 and thereafter. Continue for 7 days after the neutrophil count

Contents.Text: PREVENTION OF VIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Sandherr, M et al, Annals of Oncology 17: 1051-1059, 2006
Viral infections reactivate in a small percentage of people with malignancy.
Most viral infections in patients with hematologic malignancies or solid
tumors result from reactivation of asymptomatic latent infections,
predominantly of herpes viruses, including herpes simplex virus (HSV),
varicella zoster virus (VZV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Exogenous
respiratory tract infections caused by influenza, parainfluenza
or respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) are less common.
The main risk factor for clinically relevant reactivation is profound
disruption of cellular immune response, usually due to chemotherapy.
The duration and seerity of neutropenia are of lesser importance.
The risk of viral disease increases with the intensity and duration
of functional T-cell suppression. Patients receiving conventionally
dosed chemotherapy regimens for solid tumors experience no major
T-cell suppression and do not have a higher incidence of
This section is organized mainly by type of malignancy.

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX PROCED FOR INFECTED SKIN, SKIN STRUCTURES
Contents.DisplayText: Drugs for procedures that involve infected skin, skin structures
Contents.Text: Patients undergoing procedures for infected skin, skin structures,
Bacteremia occurs several times a day during the course of daily activities
like eating and brushing teeth and rarely results in endocarditis, even in
people with abnormal valves.  While bacteremia might occur following dental
or other procedures, most cases of endocarditis are from the millions more
episodes of transient bacteremia a person experiences per year from ordinary
daily activities.  There is no evidence that antimicrobial prophylaxis
prevents endocarditis after procedures.  The best available evidence suggests
that prophylactic antimicrobials confer more risks than benefits in most
situations.  A decision about whether to administer antimicrobial prophylaxis
should be based on both the risk of endocarditis conferred by the patient's
cardiac defect and the risk of bacteremia from a planned dental or surgical
For complete information follow this link:
Determine the need for prophylaxis through the 2-step process outlined
Step 1.  Assess the risk of endocarditis for your patient
Prophylaxis is recommended if a patient has any of the following conditions:
>>  Certain specific congenital heart conditions - refer to the full guidelines
(link above) or consult Cardiology for more detailed recommendations
>>  Cardiac transplant that develops a problem in the heart valve
Note: Prophylaxis is NO LONGER RECOMMENDED for patients with:
>>  Congenital heart conditions such as ventricular septal defect, atrial
Step 2.  Assess the risk of bacteremia from the planned procedure
Prophylaxis is indicated for these procedures:
>>  All dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue or the
periapical region of teeth or perforation of the oral mucosa. (see notes)
>>  Procedures on the respiratory tract that involve incision or biopsy of
the respiratory mucosa, such as tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy.
Prophylaxis is recommended for bronchoscopy when procedure involves
incision of the respiratory tract mucosa.
>>  Procedures that involve incision through infected skin, skin structures,
>>  Dermatologic procedures that breach the oral mucosa.
Notes: Prophylaxis is NO LONGER RECOMMENDED for these procedures:
routine anesthetic injections through noninfected tissue, taking
dental radiographs, placement of removable prosthodontic or
orthodontic appliances, adjustment of orthodontic appliances,
placement of orthodontic brackets, shedding of deciduous teeth, and
bleeding from trauma to the lips or oral mucosa.
Wilson et al.  Prevention of Infective Endocarditis:Circulation 2007

Give a single dose of tetanus-diphtheria acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) in
adults regardless of interval between most recent Td vaccine. One dose of Tdap
vaccine is given to pregnant women during each pregnancy.
Household contacts with symptomatic coughing should be treated as if they have
pertussis. Consult Infectious Diseases for all suspected cases of pertussis and
CDC recommends postexposure prophylaxis in household contacts within 21 days
after exposure to pertussis regardless of immunization history. Non-household
contacts who are at high risk of severe illness or who have close contact with
high risk individuals should receive post exposure prophylaxis within 21 days of
exposure. Those at high risk of severe illness are infants less than one year of
age, women in third trimester of pregnancy and those with preexisting health
conditions that may be exacerbated by pertussis (e.g. immunosuppressed and
asthmatic individuals). A single dose of Tdap should be administered in those
who are not up to date.
Alternative for macrolide intolerant or allergic patients
Kim et al, Annals of internal medicine (2016) 184-194

Consult Infectious Diseases for specific management advice.
Treatment Following Debridement and Retention of Prosthesis
Treat with intravenous antibiotic for 2 to 6 weeks followed by 3 to 6 months of
an oral antibiotic combined with rifampin (3 months in total hip, elbow,
shoulder and ankle arthroplasty and 6 months in total knee arthroplasty).
Treatment Following 2-stage Exchange or Resection Arthroplasty Without Planned
Treat with intravenous antibiotic for 6 weeks for all joint types.
Treat with intravenous antibiotic for 2 to 6 weeks followed by 3 months of an
oral antibiotic combined with rifampin for all joint types.
Rifampin is recommended for treatment with debridement and retention or one
stage exchange. When rifampin is combined with a beta-lactam or vancomycin in
vitro, bacterial killing is enhanced. Do not use rifampin alone, as bacterial
resistance develops rapidly. If patient does not tolerate rifampin it may be
omitted from treatment regimen. Contact Infectious Diseases for more
Chronic suppression with oral antimicrobials may follow treatment based on
MRSA or allergy to penicillin and cephalosporins:

INFECTIONS IN BONE OR JOINT PROSTHESES
Common important pathogens include coagulase-negative staphylococci,
Staphylococcus aureus, streptococci, enterococci, and gram negative bacilli.
Obtain material for gram stain and culture and base antimicrobial therapy on
results of Gram stain. Blood, joint fluid, and affected tissue and/or bone are
ideal specimens to culture. Sinus tracts are often colonized and isolates from
drainage may not be pathogens. If Staphylococcus aureus is present,it is likely
to be a pathogen in the bone.
Acute infections can often be cured with debridement with joint retention
followed by antimicrobials. Infections with duration of symptoms greater then 3
weeks or infection within 4 weeks of implantation require one or two stage
remimplantation. Cases that are inoperable can be managed with long-term
suppressive antimicrobial therapy or joint removal without replacement depending
on patient's condition. Consult Infectious Diseases (inpatient) for more
Infectious Disease and Orthopedics consultations are essential.
Empirical Therapy Before a Pathogen is Identified is Not Recommended.
If patient has sepsis or is otherwise unstable, empiric treatment before culture
results are obtained may be justified.
Up-to-Date Article: Prosthetic Joint Infections: Treatment
Osmon et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases (2013) 56.1, e1-25

Lice are parasitic insects. Human lice survive by feeding on human blood.
To make a diagnosis, use a nit comb, bright light, or lens to find a louse
The presence of nits on a hair shaft, especially when they are located more
than 6 mm from the skin, does NOT indicate active infestation.  Nits may remain
present for months after successful treatment.
Household contacts and persons who may have come into contact with personal
belongings of an infested individual should be examined for evidence of lice
and discarded or cleaned if contaminated.

Retinitis is a subset of uveitis, is rare in immunocompetent people: in these
individuals it is usually caused by varicella-zoster virus (VZV) or herpes
simplex virus (HSV). Retinitis is more common in immunocompromised patients and
cytomegalovirus being the most common pathogen in these patients. Other
retinitis pathogens include Toxoplasma gondii, Bartonella henselae, Histoplasma
capsulatum, and Treponema pallidum. In most cases, patients have other
neurological symptoms or signs.  Patients with candidemia may present with 1-3
mm white punctate retinal lesions called cotton-wool spots. These may only be
visible on fundus examination. Treatment of candidal retinitis  is systemic
antifungal therapy. Consult Ophthalmology, Infectious Diseases, or Neurology for
VZV and HSV cause nearly all cases of acute retinal necrosis (ARN), with a small
number being caused by cytomegalovirus. ARN is a rapidly progressing retinitis
that occurs primarily in immunocompetent people and can cause vision loss.
Treatment with intravenous acyclovir or valacyclovir is essential to halt

addition to a systemic antiviral may provide added therapeutic efficacy.

Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever is a tick-borne, potentially life-threatening
rickettsial disease. The highest incidence in the United States is in the
Southeastern and South-central states. Clinical diagnosis include fever in an
endemic area, known or possible tick bite, with or without rash. Rash typically
spreads from the extremities to the trunk.
Diagnosis is difficult, consult Infectious Diseases for assistance.
Consider empirical therapy with doxycycline for a patient with an undiagnosed
febrile illness and relevant tick exposure.
Sanford keyword: Rocky mountain spotted fever

Scabies is an infestation of the skin by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei.
It is transmitted by skin to skin contact. Outbreaks occur in nursing
homes, day care centers, and residential institutions.  Scabies is highly
contagious and meticulous infection control is needed.
Treatment is a single application of permethrin cream.  Some experts recommend a
second application 7-10 days after the first application if the patient is still
symptomatic or if live mites are found at that time.  Contact Dermatology or
Treat family members and other close contacts to prevent spread and recurrence.
Repeat application 7-10 days after the first application if patient is still
experiencing symptoms, or if lives mites are found.
