Name: ORZID2 GMENU SEPSIS AND SHOCK
DisplayText: Sepsis, severe sepsis, and septic shock

Contents.Item: ORZ GTX URL SOFA ONLINE CALCULATOR

Contents.Text: Per the Sepsis-3 task force, sepsis is defined as life-threatening
organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection.
The Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score can be used to help
identify organ dysfunction. An acute increase of 2 or more points in a patient
with sepsis is associated with in-hospital mortality greater than 10%. Neither
the SOFA nor the abbreviated qSOFA is sufficiently sensitive to be used as the
sole method of identifying sepsis related organ dysfunction.
Septic shock is a subset of sepsis in which profound circulatory, cellular and
metabolic abnormalities occur. Septic shock is associated with in-hospital
Early intervention is crucial to prevention of death from sepsis. Antimicrobials
active against likely pathogens and supportive treatment to maintain vascular
Reassess antimicrobial therapy daily to narrow therapeutic spectrum when culture
Treatment of Sepsis or Septic Shock

Contents.Text: Community-acquired bacterial sinusitis is most often due to Streptococcus
pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenza or Moraxella catarrhalis. Group A
Streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes are isolated less frequently.
For patients who present with severe symptoms (high fever (>/= 102 degrees
Fahrenheit, >/= 39 degrees Celsius) and purulent nasal discharge for 3-4
consecutive days or facial pain lasting for at least 3-4 consecutive days at the
beginning of illness), initiate empiric antimicrobials and obtain CT of sinuses
to determine the extent of infection. If the CT shows extension of sinusitis
infection into surrounding structures (i.e. the cranium or orbit) consult ENT
immediately. Closely monitor all patients who present with severe signs and
symptoms to ensure that signs and symptoms improve within 72 hours.
If symptoms worsen or no improvement is seen after 3-5 days of treatment,
broaden coverage, switch to different antimicrobial class and treat 10 days. If
symptoms continue to worsen or there is no improvement after 3-5 more days of
treatment, obtain CT to investigate non-infectious or suppurative causes. ENT
consultation is recommended. If sinuses are aspirated, specimens should be

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) presents with severe skin
blistering and exfoliation resulting from toxins produced by Staphylococcus
aureus.  SSSS is usually found in children and rarely in older adults.  Obtain
a skin biopsy to differentiate between SSSS and toxic epidermal necrolysis.
Initiate anti-staphylococcal therapy and obtain cultures and susceptibilities.
Empiric therapy active against both MRSA and MSSA until results available.
If cultures reveal methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), change
to nafcillin or cefazolin for better antimicrobial activity.

CDC CRITERIA FOR DIAGNOSIS OF STAPHYLOCOCCAL TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME
These criteria were developed for epidemiological purposes.  Treat cases when
fewer criteria are met if staphylococcal TSS seems likely.
Definite:  All 6 of the following criteria are met.
Probable:  Five of the 6 criteria are met.
Systolic blood pressure 90 mmHg, orthostatic drop in diastolic 15 mmHg,
Occurs 1 to 2 weeks after onset of illness and usually involving palms and
Multisystem involvement (3 or more of the following organ systems)
Vomiting or diarrhea at onset of illness
Severe myalgia or CPK elevation >2 times the normal upper limit
BUN or serum creatinine >2 times the normal upper limit, or pyuria (>5
Bilirubin or transaminases >2 times the normal upper limit
Disorientation or alterations in consciousness without focal neurologic
signs in the absence of fever and hypotension
Negative results on the following tests, if obtained
Blood, throat, or cerebrospinal fluid cultures for another pathogen (blood
cultures may be positive for S. aureus).
Serologic tests for Rocky Mountain spotted fever, leptospirosis, or measles

CRITERIA FOR DIAGNOSIS OF STREPTOCOCCAL TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME
These criteria were developed for epidemiological purposes.  Treat cases when
fewer criteria are met if streptococcal TSS seems likely.
1.)  Isolation of Group A Streptococcus from a normally sterile site (eg, blood
cerebrospinal, pleural, or peritoneal fluid, tissue biopsy, or surgical wound)
2.)  Hypotension (systolic blood pressure 90 mm Hg in adults
3.)  Two or more of the following:
(creatinine in adults, 2 mg/dL, in children, two-times upper limit of normal
for age, in patients with pre-existing renal disease two-fold elevation over
(eg, two-times upper limit of normal for age of transaminases or bilirubin, in
patients with pre-existing liver disease two-fold elevation over baseline)
Soft tissue necrosis (eg, necrotizing fasciitis, myositis, or gangrene)
Working Group on Severe Streptococcal Infections JAMA 1993, 269:390

PATIENTS WITH SIGNS OF INFECTION MORE THAN 48 HOURS AFTER PROCEDURE
Most post-operative infections appear at least 4 days after the operation.  If
the wound appears normal to examination surgical site infection is unlikely.
Seek other source of fever.  Consider opening wounds that show induration or
erythema.  Obtain material for gram stain and culture whenever possible.
Determine whether the patient has signs of invasive or systemic infection like
erythema (diameter greater than 5 centimeters), temperature greater than 38.5
degrees Celsius (101.3 degrees Fahrenheit) or heart rate higher than 100 beats
If there are no signs of invasive or systemic infection systemic antimicrobials
are unnecessary.  Dressing changes alone are indicated.
For wounds that require complicated care
If there are signs of invasive or systemic infection obtain blood cultures and
wound Gram stain and cultures.  Whenever possible select antimicrobial therapy
based on the Gram stain.  When the Gram stain cannot provide guidance give
Empirical treatment of INFECTED WOUNDS AFTER CLEAN SURGERY or wounds on the
trunk, head, neck, arms or legs
Vancomycin should be included in the initial regimen due to the prevalence of
methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  However beta-lactam antibiotics
are more effective for susceptible bacteria than is vancomycin.  If methicillin-
susceptible S. aureus is identified switch to an anti-staphylococcal beta-lactam
Preferred empirical treatment for INFECTED WOUNDS AFTER CLEAN-CONTAMINATED or
Alternative if methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is suspected

Antimicrobial prophylaxis is not indicated before cardiac catheterization
with or without stent placement or for transesophageal echocardiogram.
For patients undergoing cardiac procedures the recommended regimen is a
single pre-incision dose of antibiotic with additional doses
while incisions are open for long procedures.
Prophylaxis should not be continued beyond 24 hours
even if drains or intravenous catheters remain in place.
Cefazolin is preferred for prophylaxis, as it is more active than vancomycin
be used when methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection is likely.

DisplayText: Infomation on antimicrobial prophylaxis in urological procedures

Contents.Text: APPROACH TO ANTIMICROBIAL PROPHYLAXIS FOR UROLOGICAL PROCEDURES
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is not indicated for many procedures.  Prophylaxis is
indicated for transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), uroscopy,
transrectal prostatic needle biopsy, lithotripsy for struvite renal stones,
nephrostomy tube placement, percutaneous surgery, or other procedures where
mucosal entry is likely or the urinary tract will be manipulated.  Consult
Perform urinalysis and urine culture before a procedure where prophylaxis may be
indicated.  If bacteriuria is present treat for the organism(s) isolated from
urine.  Refer to the urinary tract infection section, or consult Urology and/or
Infectious Disease for more information.  If urine cultures cannot be done, give
Urine should be sterile before procedures involving manipulation of the urinary
tract.  For patients without chronic foley catheters, perform urinalysis and
culture before procedure, and if bacteriuria is present, treat for 2 to 3 days.
Patients with chronic foley catheters will always have bacterial urinary
colonization and therefore should not be treated unless a prosthetic device will
Urine must be sterile before procedures involving prostheses, like implantation
of penile prosthesis or artificial sphincter.  Perform urinanalysis and culture
before these procedure.  If bacteriuria is present, treat with antimicrobials
Ciprofloxacin is preferred for prophylaxis, as it is as effective as and less

Risk factors for postoperative infections following neurologic procedures
include diabetes, procedure duration longer than two to four hours, placement
of a foreign body, repeat surgery, emergency surgery, cerebrospinal fluid
(CSF) leak, postoperative intracranial pressure monitoring or presence of a
ventricular drain for more than five days postoperatively, and concurrent or
prior infection of an incision or shunt.
In spinal surgery, the infection rate after conventional lumbar discectomy is
low, but due to the severe consequences of postoperative infection at this site
antimicrobial prophylaxis is recommended. Infection rates are higher after
prolonged spinal surgery or spinal procedures involving fusion or insertion of
foreign material, and antimicrobial prophylaxis is also recommended.
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is warranted for patients undergoing clean craniotomy
CSF shunt procedures, or intrathecal pump placement.
For all other neurosurgical procedures, antimicrobial prophylaxis is not
Cefazolin is preferred for most patients as it penetrates into the cerebrospinal
fluid and is more active than vancomycin against susceptible staphylococci.
Vancomycin should be used when the patient is colonized or has been recently
infected with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  Consult Neurosurgery
or Infectious Diseases for more information.

Contents.DisplayText: Patients with signs of infection WITHIN 48 HOURS of procedure
Contents.Text: Patients with signs of infection WITHIN 48 HOURS of procedure

Contents.DisplayText: Patients with signs of infection 48 HOURS OR MORE after procedure
Contents.Text: Patients with signs of infection 48 HOURS OR MORE after procedure
Surgical site infections are categorized by the extent of tissues involved.
Superficial incisional infections involve only the subcutaneous space and occur
within 30 days of operation.  Deep incisional infections involve deep layers of
soft tissue, such as fascia and muscle, and occur within 30 days of operation,
or within 1 year of operation if prosthetic material was inserted.  Organ/space
infections involve anatomical areas other than the incisional wound that were
opened or manipulated during operation.  Organ/space infections should be
treated as infections of the relevant area of the anatomy.  Return to the main
page and choose the pertinent organ system for advice on management of these
Post-operative wound infections usually occur between 2 and 30 days after the
operation.  Infections within 48 hours of the surgery are uncommon, but are
serious when they do occur.  Symptoms commonly begin to appear no sooner than 5
days after the operation and may take up to 2 weeks to appear.

Name: ORZID2 GMENU SURG PROPHYL GENRL INFO

Contents.Item: ORZID2 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION INPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Inpt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Ip)
Potential pathogens are introduced into normally sterile areas of the body
during most surgical procedures.  The purpose of antimicrobial prophylaxis is to
reduce the intraoperative microbial burden so that local host defenses can
eliminate microorganisms and prevent disease.  Prophylaxis cannot be expected to
Antimicrobial agent for surgical prophylaxis should be:
1. active against the pathogens most likely to contaminate the surgical site
2. given in an appropriate dosage and at a time that ensures adequate serum
and tissue concentrations during the period of potential contamination
4. administered for the shortest effective period to minimize adverse
effects, the development of resistance, and costs.
Bratzler DW, et al.  Clinical practice guidelines for antimicrobial prophylaxis
in surgery, Am J Health-Syst Pharm. 2013 Vol 70 page 195-283

Duration of antimicrobial prophylaxis should not exceed 24 hours. Durations
longer than 24 hours have not been shown effective in preventing cardiothoracic
surgical site infections. There is no benefit to continuing antimicrobial
prophylaxis until all indwelling drains and intravascular catheters are removed.

TIMING AND DOSING (INCLUDING RE-DOSING) OF PROPHYLACTIC ANTIMICROBIALS
For optimal prevention, antimicrobial concentrations should be above the minimal
inhibitory concentration (MIC) of potential pathogens from initial incision
There is no advantage to giving post-operative doses. Despite a lack of
demonstrated benefit, post-operative doses are sometimes given in clinical
practice.  If post-operative doses are given, they should be discontinued by 24
hours after closure of the incision.
When prophylaxis consists of a single dose as should be the case in the majority
of procedures, adjustment for renal or hepatic dysfunction is not necessary.
The optimal time for administration of preoperative doses is 30 to
60 minutes before surgical incision for most antimicrobials.
Infusions of drugs like fluoroquinolones and vancomycin that require longer
infusion times should begin 60 to 120 minutes before first incision.
During procedures that last so long that concentrations might fall below the
MICs of potential pathogens, repeated doses of antimicrobials should be given.
Re-dosing may also be warranted if prolonged or excessive bleeding
Bratzler DW, et al.  Clinical practice guidelines for antimicrobial prophylaxis
in surgery, Am J Health-Syst Pharm. 2013 Vol 70 page 195-283

Though uncommon, most post-operative infections after urological surgery occur
when 1) a procedure is done in a person with significant bacteriuria and the
urinary mucosa is cut, 2) fecal flora enter tissues when the colon or rectal
mucosa is cut, or 3) skin flora enter tissues when the skin is cut.

PATIENTS WITH SIGNS OF INFECTION WITHIN 48 HOURS OF PROCEDURE
Fever within 48 hours of procedure is usually due to anesthesia or other non-
infectious factors but Clostridium species and Streptococcus pyogenes can cause
early infections.  Examine the wound of any patient with systemic signs of
infection, like fever, within 48 hours of surgery.  If there are signs of
infection consider opening the wound.  Obtain a STAT Gram stain and culture of
any drainage. If the Gram stain shows evidence of streptococci or clostridia
refer to the section on necrotizing infections.  If signs of wound infection are
absent seek an alternative source of the fever.

SURGICAL WOUND CLASSIFICATION AND ANTIMICROBIAL PROPHYLAXIS RECOMMENDATIONS
A wound resulting from a procedure in which no inflammation or infection was
encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary
tract was not entered.  Clean wounds are closed at the end of surgery and if
drainage is necessary wounds are closed with drains in place.
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is usually not indicated.  Exceptions are procedures
in which prosthetic material will be inserted or for operations in which a
surgical site infection would be catastrophic.  These exceptions include most
cardiac operations, joint replacement, revascularization procedures in legs, and
Clean-contaminated wounds are those in which the respiratory, alimentary,
genital, or urinary tracts are entered but there is no evidence of infection and
there is no major break in technique.  These include operations on the biliary
Antimicrobial prophylaxis is indicated for most of these procedures.
Contaminated wounds include an open, fresh, accidental wound, or operations with
major breaks in sterile technique, gross spillage from the gastrointestinal
tract, or incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered.
Antimicrobials are therapeutic and not prophylactic.
Dirty-infected wounds are old traumatic wounds with devitalized tissue and those
that involve existing infection or perforated viscera.  The organisms usually
have been present in the operative field since before the operation.
Antimicrobials are therapeutic and not prophylactic.
Bratzler DW, et al.  Clinical practice guidelines for antimicrobial
in surgery, Am J Health-Syst Pharm. 2013 Vol 70 page 195-283

Tinea capitis is a common fungal infection of the scalp and hair. It is
characterized by itchy, red, raised, scaly patches often sharply defined. The
redder margins than centers create impression of ring. Tinea capitis primarily
affects prepubescent children, but can affect people of any age.

Onychomycosis presents with yellow, thick, or crumbling nails. Obtain a
fungal stain of nail sample prior to initiating treatment. Using large nai
clippers, remove as much of the unattached dystrophic nail as possible. Place
the piece of clipped nail plate in formalin jar and send to pathology for
fungal stain (PAS). Treatment should only be initiated if stain is positive
If fungal infection is confirmed, obtain a complete blood count, liver enzymes,
and serum creatinine before starting antifungal therapy.  Re-check labs if
Clinical signs of cure may not be evident for months and successful clinical
cure is assured only when an uninfected nail has appeared in place of the
infected material.Cure can take up to 18 months. Re-treatment within a year
Complicated cases, including those without success after initial treatment,
Treat fingernail infections for 6 weeks.  Treat toenail infections for 12
Treat for 4 to 6 months or longer

Pityriasis or tinea versicolor is a common superficial fungal infection.
Patients often present with erythematous, hypo- or hyperpigmented patches,
usually on the trunk or extremities.
Topical antifungals can be used for limited disease.  For disease that involves
nails or does not respond to topical therapy, use oral antifungals.
Oily skin products or exposure to hot environments often lead to recurrences.
Return of normal skin color often takes several weeks after the treatment

Organ transplantation is associated with many host defense defects.  Early on,
surgical wounds may become infected.  Preparation for transplantation and anti-
rejection drugs can induce neutropenia.  Later, CMI defects predominate.
Patients become infected with exogenous pathogens and also endogenous pathogens
like cytomegalovirus that might have been present in latent or subclinical form.
Cell-mediated immune defects caused by anti-rejection drugs cause patients to be
especially susceptible to infections with organisms that infrequently cause
disease in healthy people.  They include: Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly
Pneumocystis carinii), mycobacteria, salmonella, candida, aspergillus,
Toxoplasma gondii, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus,
The approach to fever or other signs or symptoms suggesting the possibility of
an infectious disease depends on the specific defects present in the patient,
the nature of the presenting signs and symptoms and a bedside assessment of the
severity of illness.  Empirical antimicrobials are usually not indicated for
fever alone unless the patient has a host defense defect that predisposes to
rapid progression of illness like severe neutropenia or splenectomy.  Contact
Rich RR, et al, eds.  Clinical Immunology
Roitt I, et al, eds.  Immunology

Acute non-bloody diarrhea (< 14 days of symptoms)
Most cases are mild and self-limited. Reserve antimicrobial therapy for
patients who have severe traveler's diarrhea: pus, or mucus in stool, fever, or
Bloody diarrhea can represent hemorrhagic colitis or dysentery. Antimicrobial
therapy and antimotility agents are not recommended in most patients with bloody
diarrhea due to an increased risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome when using these
agents. Obtain a stool sample for enteric pathogen PCR testing and reserve
antimicrobial and antimotility agent treatment until results are known. Enteric
pathogen PCR testing results are reported within 2 hours between 7am and 11pm.
For more information on when an antimicrobial is indicated or if the patient has
severe/life threatening diarrhea or is immunocompromised, contact Infectious
Empiric antimicrobial treatment for non-bloody severe acute diarrhea
Primary treatment is hydration and electrolyte replacement. Empirical
antimicrobial therapy is not indicated. Attempt to make a diagnosis with, for
example, enteric pathogen PCR testing, Clostridium difficile testing in those
who used a PPI or were treated with antimicrobials in the last 8-12 weeks, and
endoscopy. If bloody diarrhea, fever, or abdominal pain/tenderness is present
the case should be evaluated by Gastroenterology and/or Infectious Diseases.

URETHRITIS ASSOCIATED WITH SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES
The main differential in a person who presents with dysuria is between cystitis
and urethritis. Bacterial urethritis is more likely in people with mild
dysuria, onset over a few days, or recent sexual contact.
The two most common sexually transmitted urethritis pathogens are Neisseria
gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Nucleic acid amplification tests for
these pathogens are more sensitive than culture and should be used for patients
at risk for sexually transmitted urethritis.
For patients who have recently been treated for urethritis
When dysuria is from a sexually transmitted disease, the patient's sexual
partner(s) during the previous 60 days should be evaluated for sexually
If diagnostic tests for the cause of urethritis are not feasible, therapy for

Initial treatment of patients and sex partners
Patients and partners are often infected with both N. gonorrhoeae and C.
trachomatis. Treat for both pathogens unless one is ruled out by lab test.

Patients with signs and symptoms of sepsis, like multiple organ system
dysfunction, shock and/or acute renal failure, should be treated as outlined in
the sepsis pathway. Early intervention is crucial to prevention of death from
Treatment for patients with signs and/or symptoms of sepsis
Obtain blood cultures before starting antibiotics when signs or symptoms suggest
bacteremia. Obtain 2 or 3 blood culture sets from different venipuncture sites
within a 24-hour period. When suspicion is strong and the patient's signs and
symptoms have not responded, obtain 2 blood culture sets the next day.
Bacteremia is discussed in more detail elsewhere:
When patients who require paraenteral therapy are afebrile, clinically stable,
and can take oral medication, convert to oral therapy based on the
identification and susceptibility of the isolate.
Antimicrobial treatment duration is based on pathogen isolated from blood
cultures and patient response to therapy, typically 7-14 days.

About half of cases of diskitis are culture negative, and many of those appear
to be uninfected.  Infectious cases often result from a surgical procedure near
the disk or back trauma.  Vertebral osteomyelitis usually results from
hematogenous seeding or directly from nearby organs.  Patients usually present
with subacute or chronic pain which is often attributed initially to other
conditions including osteoarthritis, trauma, and malignancy.
When possible obtain diagnostic cultures before starting empiric therapy.
Obtain blood cultures and image guided aspirates or surgical bone biopsy.
Definitive therapy based on culture and susceptibility test results.
The most common causes of vertebral osteomyelitis are staphylococci,
streptococci, and gram-negative bacilli. Anaerobes are uncommon pathogens.
If cultures are negative but infection is suspected, direct empirical
therapy against the most common pathogens.
Surgical intervention and spinal stabilization may be required.
Surgery and Infectious Diseases consultations are essential.
Treat for 6 to 8 weeks for low risk infections.
Treat for at least 8 weeks of pathogen-directed IV/PO therapy for high risk
including MRSA infection, ESRD, or undrained abscess or device implantation.

Contents.Text: Discontinue implicated antibiotic and avoid high risk antibiotic if antibiotic

Medium: carbapenems, penicillins, 1st generation cephalosporins, macrolides,
Very low: sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin, fosfomycin, methenamine
Avoid antiperistaltic agents (narcotics, loperamide, etc). Increasing evidence
suggests that antacid therapy, especially with PPIs and H2 blockers, increases
the risk for C. difficile disease and recurrences. Avoid antacid therapy
without clear indication, especially in patients at risk for primary recurrent C
The preferred route of antimicrobial therapy for C. difficile infection is by
mouth. Intravenous metronidazole should be used only when oral therapy cannot
be used to deliver drug to the colon. Intravenous vancomycin does not get into
colonic contents and is not effective.
C. difficile infection usually responds to antimicrobial therapy, especially if
other antimicrobial therapy has been stopped. Relapse is usually due to failure
of normal colonic flora to re-establish itself, rather than antimicrobial
treatment failure. If symptoms do not respond to appropriate antimicrobial
therapy, re-consider the diagnosis. Relapse occurs in 6% to 25% of people after
their first episode of C. difficile infection.

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION OUTPATIENT

Contents.Text: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Opt)
Sexually Transmitted Infections and HIV Exposure
Urinary tract infections (UTI) occur in patients with symptoms of infection in
the lower urinary tract (cystitis) and/or the upper urinary tract
(pyelonephritis). Cystitis refers to infection of the urinary bladder, but
inflammation often extends into the urethra. Typical signs and symptoms include
dysuria, increased urinary frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.
Uncomplicated cystitis occurs in people with structurally and neurogenically
normal urinary tract. Most cases of uncomplicated cystitis occur in
pre-menopausal, non-pregnant, sexually active young women and is associated with
Enterobacteriaceae (e.g. E. coli and Klebsiella sp.) and occasionally S.
saprophyticus. Complicated cystitis occurs in the conditions listed below and is
associated with Enterobacteriaceae, but more resistant pathogens occur,
including the Gram-positive pathogens staphylococci and enterococci. Features of
pyelonephritis include fever/other signs of systemic infection, flank pain,
costovertebral tenderness, and pelvic or perianal pain in men. In rare and
severe cases, urinary tract infections can also present with bacteremia, sepsis,
multiple organ system dysfunction, shock and/or acute renal failure.
When a patient presents with symptoms of cystitis, like dysuria, increased
frequency, and suprapubic pain, perform a urine culture. Antimicrobial therapy
is not indicated for pyuria in the absence of symptoms. Patients with signs and
symptoms of pyelonephritis should have a urinary culture and susceptibility
obtained and a urine Gram-stain performed prior to starting empirical
antimicrobials to guide therapy. Patients presenting with bacteremia, sepsis,
multiorgan dysfunction, shock and/or acute renal failure should be treated
accordingly with urinary tract as the foci of infection.
Asymptomatic bacteriuria occurs in patients who have bacteria in the urine but
do not have symptoms of a urinary tract infection. Asymptomatic bacteriuria is
Patients at risk of sexually transmitted infections should be assessed for
Candida urinary tract infections are discussed elsewhere:
Cystitis is considered complicated when one or more of the following is present:
o Structural or neurogenic abnormalities (e.g. presence of obstruction, catheter
or nephrostomy tubes, neurogenic bladder, renal failure or transplantation)
o Persistent infection, relapse, recurrence, or treatment failure
o In some cases, men and patients admitted to health care settings may be
*Bacteremia or sepsis with urinary tract source (aka urosepsis) - refer to inpt

Contents.Text: Balanitis is inflammation of the glans penis and is often associated with
erythema and pruritis. When the foreskin is also involved, the condition is
known as balanoposthitis (also referred to as balanitis in this discussion).
There are a variety of causes of balanitis, but most are due to poor hygiene of
the foreskin in uncircumcised men resulting in candida infection. Other, less
common causes, include bacterial infection (typically sexually transmitted or
anaerobic bacteria), dermatologic conditions, malignancy as well as others. Men
with Candidal balanitis often have a white curd-like exudate compared to a thick
foul-smelling purulent exudate in menu with anaerobic bacterial balanitis.

Contents.Text: COLONIZED RESPIRATORY TRACT IN A PATIENT ON A VENTILATOR
The respiratory tracts of persons who are intubated, have a
tracheostomy, or have other abnormalities of the larynx or trachea are
usually colonized with bacteria and often fungi. The bacteria can be of
relatively low virulence (e.g. coagulase negative staphylococci, streptococci,
candida) or of potentially greater virulence (Staphylococcus aureus,
enterobacteriaceae, pseudomonas). Candida and enterococci are common
respiratory tract colonizers and they almost never cause pneumonia. There is
no benefit from treatment of patients with systemic antimicrobials simply
because the respiratory tract is colonized with a potential pathogen and there
is no evidence of an infiltrate. Systemic antimicrobial therapy will select for
resistant organisms and may lead to other adverse effects.
Refer to Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for ventilator-associated pneumonia
treatment recommendations in patients with a new or progressive infiltrate and
at least one of the following: fever greater than 100.4F, leukocytosis,
Kalil et al. Clin Infect Dis, 2016, 63(5): e61-e111.

Name: ORZID3 GMENU ABX COLONIZED WOUNDS OP

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU FOOT ULCER IN PT W/ DM
Contents.DisplayText: Foot ulcer in patient with diabetes mellitus (Outpatient)

Contents.Text: Open wounds are usually colonized with bacteria and often fungi. This is true of
ulcers (see below), post-operative wounds, traumatic wounds, and others. Then
bacteria can be of relatively low virulence (eg, coagulase negative
staphylococci, diphtheroids) or of potentially greater virulence (Staphylococcus
aureus, enterobacteriaceae, pseudomonas). Candida is commonly present on wounds
that are moist or covered. There is no need to treat patients with systemic
antimicrobials simply because a wound culture is positive for a potential
pathogen. Topical antimicrobials are not effective in nearly all circumstances
and can select for resistant organisms or lead to other adverse effects.
Systemic antimicrobial therapy may be indicated if there are signs of infection.
Lipsky et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2012, 54(12): e132-e173

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION OUTPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Opt)
Contents.Text: Select here for help, legend, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Op)
Antibiotics are used to prevent infections in patients undergoing surgery in
certain well-defined circumstances. They are used to prevent surgical site
infection or to prevent endocarditis in circumstances where the risk of
endocarditis is high. For many low-risk surgeries, the risks associated with
antibiotic use, which can be severe or cause death, outweigh the benefits. The
following recommendations are consistent with guidelines published by the
American Heart Association and Infectious Disease Society of America.
In general, antibiotics are used to prevent post-operative wound infection
in clean-contaminated surgery. Most dermatological surgery involves clean
sites, and the risks of antibiotics outweigh potential benefits. Antibiotics
are used to prevent endocarditis and hematogenous joint infection in procedures
involving the oral mucosa or infected skin. Antibitic prophylaxis is also
recommended to prevent surgical site infections in procedures involving high
When they are used, prophylactic oral antimicrobial agents should be
administered 30-60 minutes before the first tissue manipulation or incision.
Intravenous antimicrobials should be administered 60 minutes (120 minutes for
Antimicrobials should not be used to prevent infections in patients with
vascular grafts or orthopedic prostheses because the risk of bacteremia or
infection of these devices is tiny and antibiotic risks outweigh any theoretical
A full course of antibiotics should be used to treat skin infections where
infection is already present at the time of surgery.
Suggested antibiotic prophylaxis regimens should be targeted against the typical
pathogens likely to be present. A risk-based approach for coverage of MRSA
should be taken in patients with specific risk factors for MRSA.
Bratzler et al, Am J Health-Syst Pharm (2013) 70, 195-283
Nishimura et al, J Am Coll Cardiol (2014) 63, e57-185

Stevens et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases (2014) 59.2, e10-52

Contents.Text: ENTERIC FEVER (INCLUDING TYPHOID AND PARATYPHOID FEVER)
Enteric fever is a systemic febrile illness caused by Salmonella enterica
serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A, B, or C. It is characterized by dramatic fever
and abdominal pain. Enteric fever typically occurs in patients who have traveled
to impoverished areas where the organisms are endemic, but can also be acquired
within the United States. Treatment is based on location of acquisition due to
increasing rates of fluoroquinolone resistance in Asia.
Antimicrobial treatment for infection NOT acquired in Asia
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS
Antimicrobial treatment for infection acquired in Asia
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS
Sanford keyword: Typhoid Fever, Enteric Fever
Shane et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases 2017, 65(12):45-80

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX HERPES SIMPLEX ESOPHAGITIS

Contents.Text: Esophagitis is usually associated with non-infectious diseases like
gastroesophageal reflux disease, mucositis and pill-induced esophagitis.
Esophageal infection occurs primarily in immunosuppressed individuals (e.g.
chemotherapy, transplantation, HIV) and rarely in healthy individuals. The
majority of infectious esophagitis is caused by Candida albicans,
cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus. Aphthous ulceration of the
esophagus is common in HIV infection.

Most acute disease is self-limited, and the virus does not cause chronic
disease. No specific antiviral therapy is available.
Patients who appear to be developing fulminant hepatitis, including those with
mental status changes should receive supportive treatment. Fulminant hepatitis
is suggested by increased prothrombin time, cholestasis, ascites, decreased
liver size, or decreasing serum albumin. Supportive treatment includes
maintenance of fluid and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction
of coagulation defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition
Prevention for persons with continuing high risk of disease
Vaccine should be offered to persons at high risk of hepatitis A infection: men
who have sex with men, travelers to endemic areas likely to be exposed, illegal
drug users, persons at occupational risk of disease, persons with chronic liver
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months
Prevention for persons with a specific, defined exposure
Post-exposure prophylaxis should be offered to persons with substantial exposure
to hepatitis A. Specifically, persons exposed to acute hepatitis through
household or sexual contact, persons who attend or work in a day care center
with a recent case, or employee or patron of a restaurant with a food handler
with hepatitis. Post exposure prophylaxis must be given within 2 weeks of
exposure. Vaccine can be given at the same time as immune-globulin.
Give Hepatitis A vaccine 1 ml IM x 2, separated by 6 to 12 months

Contents.Text: Most acute hepatitis B disease is mild and self-limited. Patients who appear to
be developing fulminant hepatitis, including those with mental status changes
should receive supportive treatment. Fulminant hepatitis is suggested by
increased prothrombin time, cholestasis, ascites, decreased liver size, or
decreasing serum albumin. Supportive treatment includes maintenance of fluid
and electrolyte balance, monitoring and possible correction of coagulation
defects, treatment of hepatic encephalopathy, and good nutrition with a low-
protein diet. Antiviral therapy is not indicated. Gastroenterology consult
Antiviral therapy for chronic hepatitis B is a complicated, highly specialized
task. Consult with gastroenterology and infectious diseases.
Vaccinate persons at high risk of disease including men who have sex with men,
illegal drug users, and health care workers with substantial exposure to blood
Give Hepatitis B vaccine 1 dose IM in deltoid at 0, then 1 or 2 months, and

Contents.Text: Ocular herpes infection can be caused by either HSV-1 or HSV-2. The majority of
cases are caused by HSV-1. The recurrence rate of ocular herpes is 40% over a 5
year period, less than that of oral or genital herpes. Ocular herpes is a
major cause of blindness and typically presents as infection of the epithelium
of the cornea but can also rarely involve the stroma and endothelium.
Involvement of the stroma or endothelium requires treatment with topical
steroid and close monitoring. For these cases, start oral antiviral and consult
Antiviral prophylaxis is recommended for patients with multiple recurrences,
recurrent episodes with ulceration, recurrent inflammation with
scar/vascularization approaching visual axis, patients who have had keratoplasty
for HSV-related scarring/astigmatism, and patients who have had HSV keratitis
while on immunosuppressive therapy. Post-surgical prophylaxis is not discussed
here. Please consult ophthalmology for more information.
Infection prophylaxis for prevention of recurrence
Reassess need for prophylaxis every 12 months
Guess et al, The Ocular Surface, (2007) 5.3:240-250
Wilhelmus, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, (2015), 1:CD002898
Miserocchi et al, Efficacy of Valacyclovir vs Acyclovir for the Prevention of
Virus Eye Disease: A Pilot Study, American Journal of Ophthalmology, 2007
White et al, Ocular Microbiology and Immunology Group and American Academy of

Contents.Text: HSV infection of the esophagus usually occurs in patients who are
immunocompromised, typically solid organ and bone marrow transplant
recipients. In healthy patients HSV esophagitis occurs occasionally,
usually in men under the age of 40.
Patients usually present with odynophagia and dysphagia. Fever
epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and heartburn are less frequent.
Some patients may have coexistent herpes labialis or oropharyngeal
ulcers. Diagnosis is usually established with an upper endoscopy.
Suggestive findings may also be seen during a barium swallow.
Spontaneous resolution usually occurs in immunocompetent patients after
one to two weeks. Patients may respond more quickly if treated with a
Treatment of mild to moderate disease
John Hopkin's Guides keyword: Herpes simplex virus

Contents.Text: HIV infection and AIDS are associated with several host defense defects. Cell-
mediated immune defects render a patient more susceptible to opportunistic
infections with pathogens like Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly Pneumocystis
carinii), Toxoplasma gondii, cytomegalovirus, mycobacterium-avium intracellulare
Contact ID or HIV (MRTC) service for assistance.
Rich RR, et al, eds. Clinical Immunology
Roitt l, et al, eds. Immunology

splenectomy and HSCT patients. Refer to specific immunization recommendations
for patients with these indications or refer to the Haemophilus influenza type b
based on shared clinical decision making.
or inhibitor use, travel to endemic countries, microbiologists, and college
students. Refer to specific immunization recommendations for asplenia and HIV or
refer to the Meningococcal A, C, W and Y vaccine information menu below.
specific immunization recommendations for patients with these indications or

Contents.Text: Metronidazole 750 mg PO TID for 10 days ($) [DI] <FOLLOWED BY> paromomycin
Serological testing for amoebiasis should be obtained in all patients with
suspected amebic liver abscess. Multiple sets of anaerobic and aerobic blood
cultures should also be obtained prior to starting antibiotics to exclude
pyogenic liver abscess, which is a much more common cause of liver abscess.
Serologic testing can be negative in a small number of patients with acute
presentation (symptoms <2 weeks). Repeat serology is usually positive. If repeat
serological testing is negative for amoebiasis or patient does not respond to
treatment of amebic liver abscess, patient should have further diagnostic
testing completed to exclude pyogenic liver abscess.
Drainage of amebic liver abscess should be considered in patients with large
Due to complicated treatment and follow up, Infectious Diseases consultation
is recommended in all patients with liver abscess.
Treatment of patients with confirmed or suspected amebic liver abscess (obtain
blood cultures prior to starting in suspected cases)
Paromomycin is nonformulary and must be ordered by Infectious Diseases.
Mandell chapter: Infections of the Liver and Biliary System

Name: ORZID3 GMENU ABX NOT BENEFITTED BACTERIURIA OP

Contents.Text: Treatment of Candida Urinary Tract Infections
Asymptomatic bacteriuria (>= 100,000 bacteria per ml of urine) is common in
middle aged and older people, especially those who have chronic medical
conditions. Pyuria is common in persons with bacteriuria and individuals with
indwelling catheters in place. By itself, the presence of pyuria is not
sufficient to diagnose bacteriuria, and the presence or absence of pyuria does
not differentiate symptomatic from asymptomatic urinary infection. Candiduria is
less common than bacteriuria, but the implications of candiduria are similar to
Many studies, including randomized clinical trials have shown that
treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria and candiduria, with or without pyuria is
of no benefit, except in certain well-defined circumstances. Antimicrobial
therapy is always accompanied by risk of harms, including drug reactions,
Clostridium difficile colitis, anaphylaxis and death. Except in circumstances
specified below, it is best to not order urinalysis or urine culture in
asymptomatic persons. If bacteriuria, candiduria or pyuria is discovered in an
asymptomatic person for some reason, antimicrobial therapy should not be given
Pregnant women or patients undergoing urological procedures with bacteriuria
Patients undergoing urological procedures or neutropenic patients with
Pappas et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2016, 62.409
Nicolle et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2005, 40:643

CONDITIONS NOT BENEFITTED BY ANTIMICROBIAL THERAPY
Several common conditions associated with inflammation or
microorganisms do not benefit from antibiotic therapy in most or all cases.
Yet, antimicrobials are frequently prescribed for these conditions leading to
unnecessary toxicity and costs, rare deaths, and the relentless increase in
antimicrobial resistance. Please review these conditions and do not give
antimicrobials for these conditions unless there are extraordinary
circumstances that make your situation different. If you have any questions,
please contact the infectious disease physician on call.

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX PAROTITIS MORE INFORMATION

Contents.Text: Infection of salivary tissue is a relatively common disease. It is usually
caused by a stone in the parotid duct, dehydration, or a viral infection.
Sialolithiasis in elderly patients often leads to ductal obstruction and
secondary infection. Other predisposing factors for ductal occlusion include
dehydration, anticholinergic medications such as tricyclics and diphenhydramine,
general disability and trauma. Once culture results are available adjust
antimicrobial therapy based on specific etiologic organism.
For more information click on the link below
Suppurative Parotitis or Chronic Bacterial Parotitis Exacerbation Empiric
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for parenteral therapy
Suspect mumps parotitis if there is fever, malaise, earache and bilateral tender
swelling of the parotid glands. For mumps parotitis treat with warm compresses
and analgesics and maintain good hydration to prevent secondary bacterial
infection. Other viral causes of parotitis include influenza and enteroviruses.
Wilson et al., Am Fam Physician. 2014, 89(11)882-888
Mandell chapter:  Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases
Up-To-Date  article: Suppurative parotitis in adults

Name: ORZID3 GMENU ABX PAROTITIS MORE INFORMATION

Contents.Item: ORZID3 GMENU ABX GENERAL INFORMATION OUTPATIENT
Contents.DisplayText: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Opt)
Contents.Text: Help, legend, allergy info, consults, alternative antimicrobials and more (Opt)
Suppurative Parotitis. Acute bacterial parotitis affects primarily elderly,
malnourished, dehydrated or post-operative patients. Symptoms include fever,
toxicity, and tender swelling along the mandible with purulent drainage from the
parotid duct. Suppurative parotitis is usually unilateral whereas viral
parotitis is usually bilateral. Pain is intense and aggressive, analgesic
therapy is required. Progression of infection may lead to massive swelling of
the neck, respiratory obstruction, septicemia and osteomyelitis of adjacent
facial bones. Empiric antibiotics are required for coverage of Staphylococcus
aureus if bacterial, and surgical drainage is usually necessary.
Chronic Parotitis. Parotitis is recurrent with intermittent acute exacerbations.
Chronic, low-grade bacterial infection results in functional destruction of the
salivary gland. It may be confused with Sjogren's syndrome, a noninfectious
illness. Therapy includes systemic antibiotics. Parotidectomy may eventually be
required for patients with long-standing infection.
Viral Parotitis. Mumps parotitis is characterized by the rapid, painful swelling
of one or both parotid glands within 2 to 3 weeks after exposure to the mumps
virus. Mumps usually involves both parotid glands whereas bacterial parotitis is
unilateral. Other viral causes of parotitis include influenza and enteroviruses.
Mumps parotitis usually resolves spontaneously in 5 to 10 days. Provide
symptomatic relief of pain and fever and maintain hydration to prevent secondary
Wilson et al., Am Fam Physician. 2014, 89(11)882-888
Mandell chapter:  Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases
Up-To-Date  article: Suppurative parotitis in adults

Contents.Text: Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (nPEP) for Exposure to Blood or Body Fluids
All persons offered nPEP should be prescribed a 28-day course of a 3-drug
* IMPORTANT- First dose should be given as soon as possible after exposure
* These medications may be taken with or without food
* Side effects of these medications are infrequent but may include:
nausea, vomiting, diarrha, rash, fever, headaches, insomnia, arthralgias,
fatigue, abdominal pain, hepatitis, renal dysfunction, rare lactic acidosis
Select appropriate treatment below based on renal function:
For non-pregnant individuals with creatinine clearance >/= 50 ml/min:
Dolutegravir 50MG Tab 1 po qday ($$)[O] for 28 days
For non-pregnant individuals with creatinine clearance 30-49 ml/min:
Dolutegravir 50MG Tab 1 po qday ($$)[O] for 28 days
For non-pregnant individuals with creatinine clearance 15-29 ml/min:
Dolutegravir 50MG Tab 1 po qday ($$)[O] for 28 days
For non-pregnant individuals with creatinine clearance <15 ml/min or dialysis:
Patient should receive all three drugs (Emtricitabine/Tenofovir/Dolutegravir)
Consult drug information for appropriate dosing for each individual drug
based on renal function. Dispense supply for 28 days.
For pregnant females or females who may become pregnant while on PEP:
(Due to risk of neural tube defects associated with Dolutegravir at
conception, Dolutegravir is not recommended to be used.)
For women of reproductive capacity who have had genital exposure to semen
and a negative pregnancy test when evaluated for possible nPEP, current
contraception use should be assessed, and if a risk for pregnancy exists,
emergency contraception should be discussed with the patient.
For pregnant females with creatinine clearance >/= 50 ml/min:
For pregnant females with creatinine clearance 30-49 ml/min:
For pregnant females with creatinine clearance 15-29 ml/min:
For pregnant females with creatinine clearance <15 ml/min or dialysis:
Patient should receive all three drugs (Emtricitabine/Tenofovir/Raltegravir))
Consult drug information for appropriate dosing for each individual drug
based on renal function. Dispense supply for 28 days.

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for Exposure to Blood or Body Fluids
A.Please review and follow the Post-Exposure Prophylaxis Protocol:
B.Order the following laboratory tests for the source patient and employee:
C.Evaluate employee for post-exposure prophylaxis antiviral medications:
If the source patient is known or suspected of having HIV infection, you are
strongly encouraged to call the infectious diseases staff physician
on call for advice any time, day or night.
If there has been a significant known or potential exposure to blood or
body fluids from a patient with HIV infection, the employee must be seen
in Occupational Health by the end of the next business day.Post-exposure
prophylaxis (PEP) medications should be recommended to the employee.If
acceptable to the employee, medications should be started within two hours of
of exposure and should be taken for up to 28 days.To get the medications
started, order a 5-day supply of antiviral medications here (see link below).
Additional medications can only be ordered by Occupational Health personnel

Name: ORZID3 GMENU ABX POSITIVE BLOOD CULTURE OP COAG NEG STAPH
DisplayText: Blood Culture Positive for Coagulase-Negative Staphylococci (outpatient)

Contents.Text: BLOOD CULTURE POSITIVE FOR COAGULASE NEGATIVE STAPHYLOCOCCI (CNS)
CNS are the most common contaminants isolated from blood cultures. When CNS
isolated from blood cultures represent true bacteremia, the blood is usually
obtained from a patient with plastic or metal in the body. The most common
source of coagulase negative staphylococcal bacteremia is an infected
When CNS are isolated from blood, the physician should carefully assess the
patient to decide whether the isolation represents disease or colonization.
Colonization is more likely if a single bottle is positive or both bottles from
a single blood draw are positive. If multiple bottles are positive from separate
blood draws, it is more likely that the isolates reflect disease or colonization
of an intravascular device. Isolates from contaminated bottles often take
several days to become positive. If the patient has risk factors for true
coagulase negative staphylococcal bacteremia, catheter-related blood stream
infection and/or the patient is severely ill, antimicrobials should be given. If
there is a plastic or metal prosthesis in the body, the physician should
evaluate the site for possible infection. If the isolates are likely to
represent contamination and the patient does not seem ill with CNS,
antimicrobial therapy would not be helpful and should not be given.
Refer to Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS for treatment CNS bacteremia and infected
Mandell chapter: Staphylococcus epidermis and Other Coagulase-Negative
Mermel et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2009, 49

PATIENTS UNDERGOING PROCEDURES THAT INVOLVE INFECTED SKIN,
SKIN STRUCTURES, OR INFECTED MUSCULOSKELETAL TISSUE
A patient with an infection involving skin, skin structures, or infected
musculoskeletal tissue may need antimicrobial for treatment of this infection
(links provided below).  If so, the antimicrobial may also reduce the risk of
endocarditis in a person with a high risk cardiac lesion.  Under these
circumstances, ensure that antimicrobial concentrations in tissues are
therapeutic for the duration of the procedure.  If the patient is not
receiving systemic antimicrobial therapy for treatment of the infection,
consider giving one dose of an antimicrobial listed below for prevention of
endocarditis in a person with a high risk cardiac lesion.
Systemic treatment for infected skin, soft tissue, muscle bone or joint
Single dose prophylaxis in a person with a high risk cardiac lesion
Pathogen unknown or possibly MSSA or beta-hemolytic streptococcus
Patients unable to take oral medications

Contents.Item: ORZ SET ABX OP RABIES STAT AND VACCINE SERIES
PSCZID TETANUS/DIPTHERIA VACCINE ONE DOSE STAT
Contents.Text: Tetanus and Diphtheria (Td) vaccine booster dose STAT
Patients are given post-exposure prophylaxis based upon their risk including
type of exposure, epidemiology of rabies in the area where contact occurred,
circumstances of the exposure incident, species and the availability of animal
involved. The Minnesota Department of Health has staff available 24/7 to consult
health care providers on risk-status of individuals. They can be contacted by
phone at 651-201-5414. Refer to link below for more information.
Discussion with Infectious Diseases inpatient attending by phone is highly
recommended. Use the link below to obtain the pager number for on-call staff.
All post-exposure prophylaxis should begin with immediate thorough cleansing of
all wounds with soap and water. After cleansing, use povidine-iodine solution to
Patients without history of rabies vaccination
After wound cleansing, administer rabies immune globulin and first dose of
Administer second, third and fourth doses of rabies vaccine series on days 3, 7,
and 14. An additional dose is given on day 28 for immunocompromised patients.
Patients with history of rabies vaccination
Patients with a history of complete pre-exposure vaccination regimen and a
documented antibody response to the rabies virus, do not require rabies immune
globulin administration. If the patient does not meet these criteria, treat as a
patient without history of rabies vaccination above. If patient does meet these
criteria, after wound cleansing, administer first dose of rabies vaccine series.
Administer second dose of rabies vaccine series on day 3.
In bite wounds that break the skin, tetanus vaccine is indicated if patient has
received <3 doses of tetanus vaccine or immunization history is unknown. Tetanus
immune globulin is also indicated in these patients if they have a tetanus prone
wound. For patients with 3 or more documented tetanus vaccine doses, tetanus
vaccine is indicated if >5 years since last booster in tetanus prone wounds and
indicated if >10 years since last booster in non-tetanus-prone wounds.
Manning SE, Rupprecht CE, Fishbein D, et al. Human rabies prevention-United
States, 2008: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization
Rupprecht, Charles E., et al. Use of a reduced (4-dose) vaccine schedule for
postexposure prophylaxis to prevent human rabies: recommendations of the
advisory committee on immunization practices. MMWR Recomm Rep 59.RR-2 (2010): 1-

3) Ensure CBOC is open on days when vaccine is scheduled to be given there. The

Contents.Item: ORZ SET ABX OP RABIES BOOSTER VACCINE ONE DOSE

Contents.Text: For patients exposed to a rabid animal, refer to the Rabies-Post Exposure
Prophylaxis recommendations in the emergency department CDSS.
People who are in high-risk groups should be vaccinated against rabies.
People with continuous risk of rabies exposure should be tested for rabies virus
neutralizing antibody every six months. Those with frequent risk of rabies
exposure should be tested every two years.
A booster vaccination should be administered if the serum titer falls to
maintain a value of at least complete virus neutralization at a 1:5 serum
dilution by the rapid fluorescent focus inhibition test.

*A vaccine series does not need to be restarted, regardless of the time that has
*For calculating intervals between doses, 4 weeks = 28 days. Intervals of 4
months or greater are determined by calendar months.
*Any vaccine can be given with another unless otherwise noted on the specific
*Mild illness is not a contraindication to receiving any vaccine.

Contents.Text: From 10% to 40% of adults are colonized with Staphylococcus aureus, and the
anterior nares is the most common site of colonization. The great majority of
people never have disease with S. aureus, but a tiny fraction of people develop
clinical infections with the S. aureus that has colonized their skin or anterior
nares. Steps to decolonize the skin and anterior nares can transiently diminish
or eradicate S. aureus colonization and can prevent post-operative wound
infection in certain high-risk circumstances. For people who have other forms
of recurrent S. aureus disease, not associated with an operation, results with
decolonization have been disappointing, and decolonization is not routinely
recommended. Colonization typically reappears in most patients within a few
days or weeks after decolonization has been attempted. Clinicians occasionlly
wish to attempt decolonization for patients with frequent, troublesome
recurrences. The procedure here is one of several that have been studied, but
none have been particularly effective over the long run.
Consultation with Infectious Diseases is recommended.

Contents.Text: SECOND RECCURRENCE OF CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE INFECTION
Patients with more than one recurrence of C. difficile infection are complex and
difficult. Commonly used treatment approaches are given below, but several
others exist.  Infectious Diseases or Gastroenterology consultation is
Discontinue any antibiotics if possible and avoid high-risk antibiotic if
antibiotic therapy is still needed. Discontinue antacid therapy if possible.
Vancomycin 125 mg PO twice daily for 7 days ($$) [R]
Vancomycin 125 mg PO q day for 7 days ($$) [R]
Vancomycin 125 mg every other day for 6 weeks. ($$) [R]
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS
Third or more recurrence: Consult Gastroenterology or Infectious Disease

Name: ORZID3 GMENU ABX STASIS DERMATITIS OP

Contents.Text: Stasis dermatitis is a common condition that is often confused with
bacterial cellulitis. Stasis dermatitis does not benefit from antimicrobial
therapy. It is important to distinguish between the two. The provider
should be mindful of the fact that bacterial cellulitis can occur on skin
with underlying stasis dermatitis. (See link below for bacterial cellulitis)
Common risk factors for venous stasis include advancing age, family
history of venous disease, increased body mass index, smoking, a history of
trauma, prior venous thrombosis and pregnancy. Chronic venous disease and
arterial vascular disease have some common risk factors (eg, smoking,
obesity) and pathophysiological processes. The most common symptoms reported
by patients with chronic venous disease are limb discomfort (tired, heavy
legs), pain, and limb swelling. Swelling is often worse with prolonged
standing and improves with leg elevation and walking. The skin of the
anterior surfaces of the lower legs often has brown or blue-grey
People with venous stasis are prone to develop stasis dermatitis which
is one of the most common and earliest dermatologic signs of chronic venous
insufficiency. Stasis dermatitis is an inflammatory process that presents as
an eczematous rash characterized by itching, erythema, scaling, weeping,
erosions, and crusting. Longstanding cases may develop lipodermatosclerosis
a fibrosing panniculitis of the subcutaneous tissue. Lipodermatosclerosis
typically starts with a firm area of induration at the medial ankle. As the
process progresses, the entire leg lower leg can become involved with
extension up to the mid leg in more advanced cases. The skin overlying the
panniculitis is typically heavily pigmented and bound down to the
subcutaneous tissues. Brawny edema above the fibrotic area and on the foot
below is seen in advanced cases. Leukocytosis and fever are common in people
Chronic venous disease is the most common cause of leg ulcers. They
are usually found low on the medial ankle over a perforating vein, or along
the course of the great or small saphenous veins. They occur more proximally
if precipitated by trauma. Venous ulcers are not found on the forefoot or
above the level of the knee. Venous ulcers can be multiple or single, and
can be exquisitely tender, shallow, exudative and have a granulation base.
The ulcer borders are usually irregular but not undermined. They can extend
circumferentially around the leg if left untreated.
Arterial ulcers are typically painful, and punched out or stellate. The
surrounding skin is red and taut. Some arterial ulcers are pale - others have
a black or yellow eschar. They are often associated with trauma and commonly
occur on the foot over pressure points. There may be other signs of arterial
insufficiency on the lower limb including thin atrophic or hairless skin,
poor pedal pulses, diminished capillary refill, or hypertrophic deformed
Patients with stasis or lipodermatosclerosis are prone to bouts of
bacterial cellulitis, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or encapsulated
streptococci. Typically, stasis dermatitis develops slowly, over a week or
more. It is often bilateral. The onset of bacterial cellulitis is usually
abrupt, typically developing over 1 or 2 days. Bacterial cellulitis often
starts in one area and spreads to adjacent areas. Bacterial cellulitis is
unilateral. Both can present with fever and leukocytosis.
In a patient with stasis and cellulitis and the physician is uncertain
about whether bacterial cellulitis is present, the physician should consider
a trial of bed rest, leg elevation, and if there is fluid overload, diuresis
If the cellulitis improves in 24-48 hours, antibacterial therapy and the
attendant adverse reactions can be avoided. If it is clear that bacterial
cellulitis has occurred, antimicrobial therapy should be given.
Stevens et al, Clin Infect Dis, 2014, 59(2): e10-52

Contents.Text: Consult Infectious Diseases in all cases. Evaluation and management are
Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the spirochete Treponema
pallidum that can manifest as a variety of signs or symptoms. Primary syphilis
typically consists of painless ulcers or chancre at the site of infection with
regional adenopathy. Secondary syphilis often includes a skin rash (disseminated
and/or including the palms and soles), fever, malaise, mucocutaneous lesions and
lymphadenopathy. Tertiary syphilis includes those with cardiovascular or
Latent syphilis is a period of disease when a patient does not have symptoms but
is found to be infected through serologic testing. Early latent syphilis refers
to latent syphilis acquired within the preceding year and late latent syphilis
refers to all other cases of latent syphilis. Neurosyphilis can occur at any
stage of syphilis with early manifestations (e.g. meningitis, stroke, vision or
hearing loss) occurring within the first months to years of infection and late
manifestations (e.g. dementia, tabes dorsalis) occurring after 10-30 years.
A presumptive diagnosis is made through use of a nontreponemal or serologic
test (i.e. rapid plasma reagin [RPR]) and a treponemal test (i.e. fluorescent
treponemal antibody absorbed [FTA-ABS]). Direct methods through darkfield
microscopy and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) must be used for definitive
diagnosis since T. pallidum cannot be cultured.
Persons with sexual contact with a person with primary, secondary or early
latent syphilis within the last 90 days should be presumptively treated even if
Alternative for patients with severe penicillin allergy who are not pregnant

Contents.Text: Upper respiratory infections include several common syndromes including
the common cold, bronchitis (see below), pharyngitis (see below) and sinusitis
(see below). Most are caused by viruses and there is no benefit from
antimicrobial therapy. If a patient presents with a URI, consider specific
infections that do respond to antimicrobial therapy like herpes simplex
stomatitis, pertussis or thrush. If no condition that benefits from
antimicrobial therapy is present, antimicrobials will almost certainly not help
but will likely select for antimicrobial resistance and may lead to other

Contents.Text: Acute bacterial prostatitis typically presents with fever, dysuria, chills,
malaise, myalgia, pelvic or perianal pain. On exam, the prostate gland is tense,
boggy, and extremely tender. The urinalysis reveals pyuria, and the urine
culture is positive. Men with dysuria and fever but without pyuria and/or
bacteriuria should be seen by a urologist. If there is any suspicion of abscess,
especially in men older than 40 years, the patient should be seen by a urologist
and transurethral prostate resection for drainage should be considered.
Most cases in men aged 35 and older, those with recent urinary tract
instrumentation or surgery (e.g., prostate biopsy, vasectomy) are associated
with enteric Gram-negative rods. Most cases in men under age 35 and those who
are at high risk of sexually transmitted infections are associated with N.
gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis. Resistant organisms are more likely if the
patient has been in the hospital for more than 48 hours or received a course of
antibiotics. There is increasing resistance in urinary pathogens to
A urine Gram stain and culture should be performed in all patients to guide
There is limited data on duration of antimicrobial treatment for prostatitis. 14
days minimum is required. 4 to 6 weeks may be necessary to completely eradicate
bacteria in the prostate to ensure patient does not progress to chronic
Hydration, bed rest and analgesics are recommended along with antimicrobials
Age < 35 years and those at high risk of sexually transmitted infections

Most cases of acute sinusitis are viral and resolve within 10 days. Symptoms
(nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, and tooth or facial pain) can be
treated with decongestants, analgesics, and nasal saline. Diagnosis of acute
sinusitis is based on the presence of at least 2 major or 1 major and at least 2
2. Purulent or discolored posterior nasal discharge
If patient meets criteria above for acute sinusitis, treat with antimicrobials
according to the following criteria for mild to moderate or severe bacterial
2. Double-sickening - Symptoms typical of viral upper respiratory infection
initially improving for 5-6 days then worsening with new development of fever,
Severe signs or symptoms of high fever (>/= 102 degrees Fahrenheit, >/= 39
degrees Celsius) and purulent nasal discharge for 3-4 consecutive days or facial
pain lasting for at least 3-4 consecutive days at the beginning of illness.

Contents.Text: Community-acquired bacterial sinusitis is most often due to Streptococcus
pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae or Moraxella catarrhalis. Streptococci,
Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes are isolated less frequently.
Treatment for first 10 days of illness
Treat with decongestants, analgesics, and nasal saline spray.
Treatment of cases that have not improved in 10 days despite
treatment with decongestants, analgesics, and nasal saline.
If symptoms worsen despite 72 hours or  fail to improve after 3-5 days of
initial empirical antimicrobial therapy, broaden coverage, switch to different
antimicrobial class and treat 7-10 days. If symptoms continue to worsen or there
is no improvement after 3-5 more days of treatment, obtain CT to investigate
non-infectious or suppurative causes. ENT consultation is recommended. If
sinuses are aspirated, specimens should be cultured.
Chow et al, Clinical Infectious Diseases. 2012, 54(8) e72-e112
Meltzer et al, J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2004, 114(6) S155-S212.
Rosenfeld et al, Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery. 2015, 152(4) 598-609

Contents.Text: Community-acquired bacterial sinusitis is most often due to Streptococcus
pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenza or Moraxella catarrhalis. Group A
Streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes are isolated less frequently.
For patients who present with severe symptoms (high fever (>/= 102 degrees
Fahrenheit, >/= 39 degrees Celsius) and purulent nasal discharge for 3-4
consecutive days or facial pain lasting for at least 3-4 consecutive days at the
beginning of illness), initiate empiric antimicrobials and obtain CT of sinuses
to determine the extent of infection. If the CT shows extension of sinusitis
infection into surrounding structures (i.e. the cranium or orbit) consult ENT
immediately. Closely monitor all patients who present with severe signs and
symptoms to ensure that signs and symptoms improve within 72 hours.

Contents.Text: SBP is infection of the peritoneal cavity in the absence of apparent trauma or
other obvious cause. SBP occurs primarily in people with end-stage liver disease
and ascites. The diagnosis is made when a peritoneal fluid sample has >/= 250
polymorphonuclear leukocyte cells per microliter, or when bacterial pathogens
Long-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients who experience a first
episode of SBP. Short-term SBP prophylaxis is indicated for patients with
variceal bleeding, or for patients who have low-protein refractory ascites (<1
gm albumin/dl ascitic fluid). Some give long-term antimicrobials to patients
with low-protein refractory ascites. Consult Gastroenterology for more
Refer to the Inpatient Antimicrobial CDSS

PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Chemotherapy with purine analogues such as fludarabine, cladribine, or
pentostatin results in major cellular-immunodeficiency that may outlast the
exposure by months and enhances the risk for viral infections.
Recommend antiviral prophylaxis for patients treated with purine analogues
if at least one of the following risk factors is present:
e) Prolonged Mild or Moderate Neutropenia: Mild<1000 Neutrophils /
µL (Grade III neutropenia) OR Moderate: <500 Neutrophils/µL
Duration: Antiviral prophylaxis should be initiated in the first week of
therapy and continued until 2 months after completion of therapy.
Alemtuzumab is a potent reactivator of latent intracellular pathogens,
including CMV. Chemotherapy with alemtuzumab results in major cellular-
immunodeficiency that may outlast the exposure by months and enhances the
risk for viral infections. The risk of viral disease increases with the
intensity and duration of functional T-cell suppression experienced with
Duration: Initiate antiviral prophylaxis with alemtuzumab therapy and
continue therapy for at least 2 months after last dose or until CD4 counts
are greater than or equal to 200 cells/ul, whichever is later.
Mandel Chapter: Prophylaxis and Empirical Therapy of Infection in
Sandherr,M et al, Annals of Oncology 17: 1051-1059, 2006

PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Prophylaxis for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) or Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
Prophylaxis for Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses
Patients with active malignant disease are at higher risk for upper
respiratory infections due to influenza, parainfluenza or respiratory
syncytial virus (RSV). Although response to vaccination with the attenuate
influenza vaccine in patients on chemotherapy is variable, ranging
from 24-75%, immnunoprophylaxis with the influenza vaccine is recommended
patients with active malignant disease or chemotherapy, lymphoproliferative
disease, or multiple myeloma. In areas and seasons where influenza is
endemic, chemoprophylaxis can be considered in addition to vaccination in
exposed patients with a high risk of influenza complications.
Prophylaxis and monitoring for CMV reactivation is not recommended unless
patient has received an allogeneic HSCT. Usually the recommendations for
surveillance and prophylaxis of CMV infections from the institution
performing the HSCT will be followed.
Reactivation of chronic hepatitis B in patients undergoing immunosuppressive
or antineoplastic treatment is a severe complication. Patients with positive
HBsAg, chronic hepatitis B infection, or a previous episode of HBV
reactivation who will receive immunosuppressive therapy should receive
Recommend routine testing for Hepatitis B prior to initiating Rituximab
Mandel Chapter: Prophylaxis and Empirical Therapy of Infection in
Sandherr, M et al, Annals of Oncology 17: 1051-1059, 2006

PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Viral infections reactivate in a small percentage of people with malignancy
Most viral infections in patients with hematologic malignancies or solid
tumors result from reactivation of asymptomatic latent infections,
predominantly of herpes viruses, including herpes simplex virus (HSV),
varicella zoster virus (VZV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Exogenous
respiratory tract infections caused by influenza, parainfluenza
or respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) are less common.
The main risk factor for clinically relevant reactivation is profound
disruption of cellular immune response, usually due to chemotherapy.
The duration and severity of neutropenia are of lesser importance.
The risk of viral disease increases with the intensity and duration
of functional T-cell suppression. Patients receiving conventionally
dosed chemotherapy regimens for solid tumors experience no major
T-cell suppression and do not have a higher incidence of

Contents.Text: The decision to treat should be based on clinical symptoms and/or presence of
a high risk condition, and should NOT be delayed until laboratory test
It is important to use antiviral drugs early to treat influenza in people who
are very sick with influenza (for example hospitalized people) and people who
are sick with influenza and have a greater chance of getting severe
complications. If a patient is not in a high-risk group or is not hospitalized,
healthcare providers should use clinical judgment to guide treatment decisions.
People who have a greater chance of serious influenza complications include:
*Persons who have chronic pulmonary (including asthma) or cardiovascular
(except isolated hypertension), renal, hepatic, hematologic, metabolic
*Persons who are immunocompromised due to any cause (including immunosuppresion
caused by medications or by HIV infection)
*Persons younger than 19 years of age who are receiving long-term aspirin-
or salicylate-containing medications and who might be at risk for experiencing
Reye syndrome after influenza virus infection
*Persons who are extremely obese (BMI greater than or equal to 40)
If indicated, antivirals should be started as soon as possible.  Maximal
benefit occurs when started within 48 hours of symptom onset.  However,
antivirals should not be withheld if symptoms began more than 48 hours prior
and the patient meets criteria for treatment and remains severely ill.
Extending the duration of treatment for oseltamivir may be needed
for those patients with prolonged illness or who are immunosuppressed.
*Pregnant women and women up to 2 weeks after the end of pregnancy
*Non-Hispanic Black persons, Hispanic or Latino persons, and American Indian

PREVENTION OF ANTIVIRAL INFECTIONS IN A PATIENT WITH MALIGNANCY
Solid tumors do not significantly compromise the cellular immune system.
Therefore, patients are at low risk for opportunistic viral infections.
Documented invasive viral infections are very rare. Coincidental
mucocutaneous infections by herpes simplex are easily treated and do not
result in life-threatening invasive infections. Reactivation of
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) or Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is rarely observed.
In patients with acute leukemia, treatment is highly aggressive and consists
of a combination of various cytotoxic agents administered in sequential
cycles as induction, consolidation and maintenance therapy. Persistent, i.e.
>10 days and profound neutropenia (<500 neutrophils) regularly occurs and
correlates with the risk of developing fever and infections. Almost all viral
infections during neutropenia constitute reactivations of herpes viruses.
None of the available studies demonstrated an effect of antiviral prophylaxis
on the initiation of antibiotic treatment, number of febrile days, duration
of antibiotic treatment, and onset of opportunistic infections. Therefore,
recommendation for antiviral prophylaxis in patients with acute leukemia can
Rituximab is a monoclonal anti-CD-20 antibody used for treatment of
lymphomas. It leads to a profound depletion of circulating B-cells. B-cell
recover usually within 3-6 months after treatment. Prolonged administration
of rituximab (e.g., maintenance treatment >12 months) may result in a
significant decrease of levels of immunoglobulin M. Parvovirus B19 and JC-
papovavirus infections have been reported with maintenance rituximab therapy
but drugs that would prevent these infections are not available. There is
substantial increase in risk of reactivation of herpes viruses (including
Recommend routine testing for Hepatitis B prior to initiating Rituximab
